story:
Summary

After hearing the story about Ahmed Mohamed from Irving, Texas, we decided to do something to help STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math) education in immigrant communities. We're bringing a little humor and creating a clock in the shape of a cartoon bomb. 

When you buy this clock, all profits will be used to create a scholarship fund for school STEM programs in high schools across the US.

The Clocks

You can buy one of three clock models. All clocks will be made from black glossy hard plastic. The first is the "Bomb Math Clock", with mathematical expressions on the dial instead of number. The "Bomb Numbers Clock" will have standard numbers. Finally, the "Round Math Clock" will be round, but will have the math face.

The price is the same. If you buy any clock, you are contributing to the scholarship fund.

The Scholarship Fund

After subtracting costs, all the  money from this campaign will be donated to a scholarship fund that gives grants to schools serving predominantly immigrant communities.

The fund will look at the following factors when determining grants:

  1. Only fund STEM programs and departments.

  2. Any teacher or school in the US can apply.

  3. At least 20% of students affected by the proposal must be children of immigrants.

  4. Proposals will be ranked based on creativity, educational value, and the financial need of the school.

  5. Public institutions only. No private schools.

  6. Proposals must include specific equipment and program acquisitions.

  7. $1,000 to $10,000 per grant (or more if we raise more money).

Sample projects that would be funded are the purchase of robotic kits, chemistry kits, telescopes, microscopes and other lab equipment. Trips to labs, museums or animal sanctuaries. Competitions and fairs. Basically anything that inspires kids to pursue STEM.

Why?

Immigrants face many challenges. Their daily struggles usually don't elicit a national outcry. Instead they have to pull themselves up by their own courage after being beaten down, and with help from unsung heroes all over the country that understand the value of education and human dignity.

This project is about science. It's about education. It's about fairness and opportunity. Your clock tells everyone where you stand. And, if we are successful in this campaign, your support will help immigrants pursue their dreams through our scholarship fund.

Our Real-life Immigrant Actors




   

Manufacturing Process

There are a few things we need to do before you get your clock. 

  • Create molds for the unique clock shape, which is the most expensive step.
  • Print the custom clock faces.
  • Manufacture the clock housing.
  • Create the custom "fuse".
  • Procure quartz clock movements.
  • Assemble the parts.
  • Create packaging.
  • Ship them to you.

To do all this, aside from the manufacturing and shipping costs, we need to hire consultants, artists and engineers. We also need to pay Indigegogo commission, public relations and marketing expenses to get the word out.

All of this takes time and money. When the campaign closes, we will begin the manufacturing process for delivery in March 2016.


Shipping

Unfortunately, we can only ship to the US, Canada or European Union. If you are outside that area, you can use a service like Shipito (shipito.com) that for a fee will forward a package to you.

Who's running this thing?

We are college graduates and we are grown adults with decades of business experience. Together, we bring the enthusiasm and experience necessary to make this project a reality.

Raghu Adinarayanan: I have been an IT and management consultant for about 20 years helping clients implement multi-million dollar IT transformations. I have built and managed large teams, budgets, expenses and built my brand around truly becoming a trusted advisor for my clients and most importantly delivering results. So I understand and take pride in delivering on promises, have the expertise in dealing with finance, schedule and project management. Between Fernando and I, we are committed and have the expertise to make this campaign a success and help the schools and the students.

Fernando Trias: I began my career as an analyst at the Federal Reserve and then spent 6 years at Fidelity Investments, working as an analyst in the Global Equity Trading Desk. I also the co-founder of PAES, an analytics firm specializing in Microfinance in developing economies. I was also a co-founder and board member of Pedestal Software, a computer security provider. I have also advised many startups in the Boston area. So I'm very familiar with finance, investments, lawyers and complicated deals. I also have experience manufacturing electronic and computing devices.

Legal Process

Our plan is that the scholarship fund will take the form of a Foundation, which requires legal and accounting advice to set up. First, the Foundation needs to be incorporated and all documents created. A Board of Trustees will be established. Each person who donates to this project may choose to become a founding member and receive a certificate. Only donors to this Indiegogo or the fund can be elected to the Board of Trustees. Once the legal entities are created, the money from this campaign, after costs, will be transferred to bank accounts owned by the Foundation. 

Open Source Design

Once the campaign is successful, we will create files and an instructional video for creating your own clock using any existing plastic clock and other common parts. For the more ambitious, we will publish all our clock faces, materials lists and 3D models so you can create your very own bomb clock from scratch.

The clock in our videos was constructed by using a MakerBot 3D printer to modify an existing clock, attaching parts with a combination of silicone adhesive and hot glue. The face was designed on Inkscape printed on a laser printer. The hands and body were painted the appropriate color using a combination of acrylic paint and spray paint. The fuse is a nylon rope with a metallic core.

Risks & Challenges

The first challenge will be building the clocks. We have researched and contacted manufacturers. Manufacturing constraints may necessitate a change in color or finish and perhaps minor changes to the shape of the clock or the hands. We won't know for sure until we know how many clocks we have to build after this campaign closes.

The second challenge is distributing the money to schools in need. We will either find a foundation aligned with our goals or create one with a Board of Trustees to oversee it. There are legal hurdles and tax implications for every decision. Part of the money will be spent on lawyers and accountants to make sure everything is done right. Even more challenging will be sorting through the applications and making funding choices.

Donations and Sharing

If you like our goals, please share this project with your friends.

We also accept direct donations to the scholarship fund. Your donations will not be used to pay for any manufacturing costs, so it goes directly to help schools. If you are interested in donating more than $100, please contact us directly for more information.

Between Fernando and I, we are committed and have the expertise to make this campaign a success and help the schools and the students.


Fernando Trias: I began my career as an analyst at the Federal Reserve and then spent 6 years at Fidelity Investments, working as an analyst in the Global Equity Trading Desk. I also the co-founder of PAES, an analytics firm specializing in Microfinance in developing economies. I was also a co-founder and board member of Pedestal Software, a computer security provider. I have also advised many startups in the Boston area. So I'm very familiar with finance, investments, lawyers and complicated deals. I also have experience manufacturing electronic and computing devices.
Legal Process
Our plan is that the scholarship fund will take the form of a Foundation, which requires legal and accounting advice to set up. First, the Foundation needs to be incorporated and all documents created. A Board of Trustees will be established. Each person who donates to this project may choose to become a founding member and receive a certificate. Only donors to this Indiegogo or the fund can be elected to the Board of Trustees. Once the legal entities are created, the money from this campaign, after costs, will be transferred to bank accounts owned by the Foundation. 
Open Source Design
Once the campaign is successful, we will create files and an instructional video for creating your own clock using any existing plastic clock and other common parts. For the more ambitious, we will publish all our clock faces, materials lists and 3D models so you can create your very own bomb clock from scratch.
The clock in our videos was constructed by using a MakerBot 3D printer to modify an existing clock, attaching parts with a combination of silicone adhesive and hot glue. The face was designed on Inkscape printed on a laser printer. The hands and body were painted the appropriate color using a combination of acrylic paint and spray paint. The fuse is a nylon rope with a metallic core.
Risks & Challenges
The first challenge will be building the clocks. We have researched and contacted manufacturers. Manufacturing constraints may necessitate a change in color or finish and perhaps minor changes to the shape of the clock or the hands. We won't know for sure until we know how many clocks we have to build after this campaign closes.
The second challenge is distributing the money to schools in need. We will either find a foundation aligned with our goals or create one with a Board of Trustees to oversee it. There are legal hurdles and tax implications for every decision. Part of the money will be spent on lawyers and accountants to make sure everything is done right. Even more challenging will be sorting through the applications and making funding choices.
Donations and Sharing
If you like our goals, please share this project with your friends.
We also accept direct donations to the scholarship fund. Your donations will not be used to pay for any manufacturing costs, so it goes directly to help schools. If you are interested in donating more than $100, please contact us directly for more information.

story:
WHY OREGON? WHY OREGON STUDENTS?

Established in Eugene/Springfield Oregon, OBEF is uniquely situated in a small population state nestled between Washington and California, with a small minority population but with dynamic institutions of higher learning and fantastic business and community leadership opportunities.  OBEF wants all students to be able to take advantage of what Oregon has to offer. 

OBEF's purpose is to provide tangible transitional education opportunities; promote equity to eliminate disparities and value diversity while working with High Schools, Community Colleges, and University students.  This effort will  emphasize traditional education or technical skills training that galvanizes the entrepreneur spirit for future business leaders and a commitment to community for all leaders.  

OBEF champions funding support for needful students in pursuit of furthering their education or vocational training goals by awarding scholarships with funding obtained through meetings, networking special events, and projects executed by the Board members.

OBEF was originally organized by community leaders from all walks of life in 2011 as the Oregon Black Business Alliance by a prominent business woman with a vision.  The name was changed in 2012 to OBEF and became a 501 (c) (3) organization in  2013.    

Mentoring in partnership with the University of Oregon’s Lundquist College of Business to assist and develop future business leaders was a key component of the initial goal of OBEF as well as mentoring with a local alternative high school.  

THE NEED

  • Starting with $5,000, the plan is to award 5 - $1000 scholarships per year
  • You will receive a personal thank-you from the recipient and have the opportunity to follow their career if so desired.    
  • If the entire goal is not reached, the funds collected will be equally dispersed to 5 students who will submit an application.  This is a needs based scholarship, all student residents in Oregon are eligible to apply.  Local schools preferred.

THE IMPACT

  • We know all too well how expensive higher education is these days and the degree to which students are saddled with enormous debt. 
  • We recently awarded a $500 scholarship to a student who shared that it would be used for books and supplies at community college.  
  • A track record of funding with OBEF will put us in a competitive position for other funding sources in the future. 
  • The obstacles: funding is often scarce even in good economic times; we have several fund raising events planned and will retool as needed based on our successes and challenges.  

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

  • Please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign!
  • Please visit our website oregon-black-education-foundation.org for more information/activities and like us on Facebook. 
  • If you shop on Amazon, please designate Oregon Black Education Foundation on the Smile.Amazon charitable giving program.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
If a song ever turned your life around...
If marching band shaped your life...
If you had the best theatre teacher who believed in you...
If you picked up a clarinet in the 4th grade and it was the beginning of something bigger...
If music ever made you feel alive...

This is your chance to pay it forward and say thanks.


Hi my name is Diana and I want to open a music school in the Glendale/Burbank area of Los Angeles.

I am a composer/songwriter/music teacher (15+ years) who loves kids.  I teach out of my home as well as at an elementary school.  I am an experienced business owner who truly loves children and music.   I grew up having almost nothing, yet ended up an adult working as a music composer with my music in television, film and commercials, all with the help of public music programs, music lessons and a lot of hard work.  I want to help children by opening a local and affordable music school.  I am passionate about bringing a musical hub to this area of town not necessarily known for culture.

Public music programs are shrinking or disappearing completely.  As a teacher, I’ve seen the powerful changes music lessons can make in a child's life: from learning how to focus and achieve goals to discovering something special about themselves that they never knew was there.  With funding through Indiegogo, I can offer at least 10 full financial scholarships in my first year.

"You have two hands, one for helping yourself, the other for helping others."
                                                                                                   -Audrey Hepburn


In order to open this music school, I will need to rent a commercial storefront where I can build sound-proofed practice rooms, a waiting area and a small performance space.  I will need to paint the exterior/interior and have a sign and awnings made.  Furniture can be found on Craigslist on a strict budget.  There will be costs for permits and paperwork.   I can defray my startup costs AND offer 10 scholarships immediately if I meet my funding goals.  Financial scholarships will include providing an instrument, personal instruction, and all educational materials.  If we go beyond my funding goals, it will allow us to extend these first scholarships and give additional scholarships.  I would like to have the scholarship recipients post anonymous updates on a blog website so we can all be a part of their journey.  

If we allow music instruction to be only for the few with the means, we silence so many that also have something valuable to say with their art.  I want to give as many children as possible this same chance at having something special in their lives.  If we can reach enough people, even $20 will a big difference in meeting our goal.  Can we fund 10 scholarships this year?  Absolutely!  Can we fund more than that?  Let's see!   

This music school and these scholarships and WILL change lives. 

“There is no exercise better for the heart than reaching down and lifting people up.” 
                                                                                                          - John Holmes

story:
How It All Began

My name is Gabriel Harter and I am an active composer and musician who's been inspired by Japanese music for years. In September of last year I applied for a foreign exchange program to spend my senior year in Japan through the organization CIEE. Only one or two American students are accepted into this program each year. I was fortunate enough to be one of the accepted applicants and am now faced with the prospect of raising the required funds to participate in this exchange.

Having heard stories of Japan as a child, the country, which was once so distant, is now a realistic destination for me to pursue my future as an international and multicultural musician. As a contributor, you will not only be helping me to pursue a lifelong ambition, but you will be helping me to further the development of a more universal musical self. You will be helping to spread the beauty of different cultures through the global language of music.

Don't forget to check out my interview on Vermont Public Radio.

My Goal

My current funding goal is four thousand four hundred and forty-four dollars. 100% of your contribution will go to CIEE to pay their safety and tuition fees for the year long exchange to Japan, or the gap year program.

My Inspiration

My biggest inspiration as a composer comes from the composer Joe Hisiashi, who scored many films for director Hayao Miyazaki of Studio Ghibli. In his film Mononoke Hime (Princess Mononoke), Hayao Miyazaki presents heroes and villains who are neither entirely benevolent nor entirely evil. He presents a sort of duality in human nature that people tend to reject in favor of a more narrow minded view. This idea is delivered through not only picture, but sound, as Joe Hisiashi weaves his music powerfully into the texture of the film. Emotions intertwine with artistic vision as the powerful music bolsters the rich story and unique message.  I truly hope that my music may be able to affect people in a similar way.

My Music

My music is the sonic conceptualization of various ideas that I have in reaction to the world around me. It's difficult to articulate. When I feel a certain way, happy, sad, I feel so in sound. I assume that the sounds I feel are similar to the sounds other people feel, so when I write my music I am in a sense communicating directly with the listener’s sense of emotion: what sounds they might they feel in relation to what emotion. The ideas that are the original inspirations for the feelings which I translate into sound may or may not be understood by the listener as I understand them. But, this is the beauty of music. Those feelings that are received can be felt by anyone, regardless of what ideas they associate them with. So in a grander sense, I think of my music as emotion, mutually tangible, though connected to a world of possible interpretations.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're not able to contribute, you can still help. Please share this campaign on your Facebook or Twitter. 

Why 4,444 dollars? 

In Japanese culture, the number 4 is associated with bad luck. This is my attempt to turn that bad luck into good luck, and overcome the power of 4.

story:
Aliim

Aliim is a non-profit organization whose mission is to leverage technology and mentors to provide refugees and marginalized youth access to safe, quality, and relevant education.


Smartphone Schools Program

Aliim’s Smartphone Schools Program is the first mobile learning program that aims to empower Syrian refugee youth living in the Levant or migrating to other regions of the world, to continue their education and access better economic opportunities through technology and a global network of mentors. We have developed a theoretical framework to contextualize our curriculum in order to better address the specific needs of Syrian refugees – with a focus on girls – and adapt to the resources available in a particular conflict-affected setting. Students can access the program's learning content through an application, with on-line and off-line functionality. If successful, our program model can also be tailored to other conflict or emergency contexts. We expect to later extended mobile learning programs to the MENA region, along with Africa and Asia, where the need for education is extensive. 


"App Provides Education For Migrants On The Move"

On December 29, 2015 CNN's Alison Kosik interviewed Aliim's Founder & CEO, Janae Bushman live about this crowdfunding campaign and about our smartphone drive (see aliim.org for information about the drive). 

See the link below to watch the CNN video. 

"App Provides Education For Migrants On The Move"


"Technology and smartphones could help to educate refugees"


On November 30, 2015 CNBC's Luke Graham, published about our innovative Smartphone Schools Program and the impact our program can have on refugees. 

See the link below to read the article.

   "Technology and Smartphones Could Help to Educate Refugees"


2.7 Million Syrian Out-Of-School Children

Following 4 years of conflict, more than 2.7 million Syrian children don’t have access to any kind of education. Many of them have missed out on 2 to 3 years of school and are now verging on becoming a lost generation.

With each lost year of schooling, the chance that these youth will return to formal education greatly diminishes, leaving those who will eventually be responsible for rebuilding their country with little hope for a future.

Girls Are Particularly at Risk

While the rate of child and forced marriage was already significant in Syria before the war, it dramatically increased following the current crisis, excluding girls from the secondary school system and exposing them to dangerous early pregnancy or a higher risk of domestic violence. In Lebanon, 18% of Syrian girls, ages 15 to 18 are married (against 2% for boys).

Many reports highlight the fact that girls are more likely to be kept at home as a consequence of security issues, especially sexual and gender-based violence, which are realities of the life in refugee camps. To learn more about the dramatic consequences of the Syrian crisis on girls, click here.

Malala's Voice

The Nobel Peace Prize winner, Malala Yousafzai, is especially an inspiration to us at Aliim. Malala recently built a school in Lebanon for Syrian refugee girls. We believe that mobile learning can extend the work of organizations like the Malala Fund, to bring education beyond the walls of the classroom and into the hands of refugee girls who cannot come to school. With permission from the Malala Foundation, we wanted to share a beautiful short film that lends Malala's voice to the urgency behind reaching out to refugee girls and the impact we all can have as we work towards including  more girls in formal or non-formal education. 



Education Is the Key

Education is more than a fundamental human right. It is essential to the exercise of all other human rights. By also providing youth with the right tools to understand the world they live in and empowering them to fully and positively take part in the society, education is crucial to achieving global goals. At Aliim, we believe that education is the key to a better world.

In the specific context of the Syrian crisis, education can mitigate some of the risks that refugees face, especially girls. Safe learning environments can protect them from getting trapped in cheap labor or early marriage and empower them to stand for their rights.


Our Plans for 2016

Based on the results of a field survey we conducted in Lebanon and several recent publications on refugee educational needs, we have developed a theoretical framework to contextualize our curriculum in order to better address the specific needs of Syrian refugees – with a focus on girls – and adapt to the resources available in a particular conflict-affected setting.

We are now seeking donations to launch the Smartphone Schools pilot program in Sidon and Akkar, Lebanon. Aliim will use 100 percent of the proceeds to develop out the program, including:

1) Developing the program’s curriculum further and uploading it to the mobile learning platform;

2) Provide students with basic smartphones ($40 each) and solar panels for charging, along with wifi and data plans;

3) Staff salary on the ground in Lebanon to oversee the implementation of the program;

4) Provide TOEFL tests for each student learning English; and

5) Impact evaluations to ensure we are effectively meeting the program’s learning objectives.

We can provide all this for just under $34 a month per student ($300 per student for a full school year), with a goal of serving 250 Syrian refugee children ages 12 to 16 (mainly girls) in the pilot program.

What if we don’t reach our goal?

Every dollar counts. We are currently looking for corporate partners and applying for grants and will keep up our fundraising efforts until the pilot program is launched.

What if we exceed our goal?

The more we bring in during this campaign, the more out-of-school students we we can reach and enroll into our program. $75,000 USD is the minimum to get started, which provide Smartphone Schools to 250 refugees for a full school year. Beyond the baseline goal, our stretch goal is $150,000, with which we can reach hundreds of additional refugee children. 


Learn More About Our Unique Curriculum

Our Smartphone Schools Program is not only about giving out-of-school Syrian youth the chance to acquire crucial knowledge and encouraging them to study further. It aims at empowering the next generation of Syrians, especially girls, to have a positive impact on their new community within their country of asylum. It also prepares youth to become active contributors to both the local and global economy, and eventually participate in reconstructing Syria when the war is over.

To reach these goals, and based on the results of our needs assessment, we designed our curriculum to include relevant skills, special learning features, and a series of innovative pedagogical tools to make our program unique.

Our International Mentor Network

Our Smartphone School program includes interaction with an international network of mentors who will accompany students throughout the nine months, giving them feedback and answering their questions. With mobile technology, our mentors can live anywhere in the world. We believe that mentoring is an essential aspect of the program. By giving youth the opportunity to obtain the support they need from people all around the world, we intend to create a real community, allowing them to get guidance even after they finish the program, and eventually opening them professional opportunities.

Giving Children a Voice

If we bring school to youth through technology, why not leverage this channel to give them a voice? Our blog “Voices of Peace” will be a platform for students and youth around the world to interact with each other and the global community by sharing poetry, essays, photography, and artwork.

Our English Module

Beyond limited spots for Syrian refugees in public schools, one of the main obstacle for Syrian youth to access education in their host countries is language. This is particularly the case in Lebanon, where education is taught in English and French. Our English curriculum will be designed to prepare students to TOEFL certification in order to facilitate their integration into formal schools. Beyond this aspect, English skills can make a huge difference for Syrian refugees who continue their journey in other countries, especially in Europe, where the majority arrives with little other language skills than Arabic, experiencing crippling communication issues.

Our Citizenship Module

The goal of Aliim’s Citizenship curriculum is to empower students to engage with their new community in a positive way, enjoy and exercise their rights, and to think critically about their surrounding and society, looking to credible information sources to help them in this process. We are convinced that our students could have an even greater impact on their environment by diffusing these values.

Besides lessons on basic Human Rights, the curriculum will include a special focus on tolerance and gender equality. We want girls to be aware of their rights and boys to stand up for them.The citizenship curriculum will also provide students concrete information on local institutions and organizations in order for them to know who to turn to in case they encounter specific difficulties.

Our Entrepreneurship Module

The Entrepreneurship curriculum will present foundational business concepts with a special focus on innovation and solution finding. More than knowledge, this curriculum aims at inspiring our students to dare dream of a better tomorrow and  what we would like to provide them with the Entrepreneurship module.


Get to Know Aliim's Team

In a mobilized world, we believe that it is possible to fulfill every child’s right to education.

Aliim’s team is a global network of individuals who share a passion for technology and the ways we can leverage it to achieve global goals. We are committed to helping marginalized youth to reach their full potential by providing them access to education and empowering them to fully take part in the society.

From the United States to Lebanon, Germany, Mexico, the Netherlands, and Uganda, Aliim’s team’s member combine over 40 years of experience in  teaching, curriculum design, finance, marketing, management consulting, human rights law, e-commerce, engineering, programming, strategic planning, evaluations, data analysis, fundraising, and program implementation.

Local Partners

Aliim works with local partners including, the Center for Applied Research in Education (CARE) at the University of Notre Dame, Louaize. CARE and our other partners help us connect the needs of the local communities with our mobile learning curriculum to ensure we provide the most relevant and applicable skills in a way that follows international education in emergency guidelines.


What Motivates Us

Echoes From a Lost Generation, Janae’s Grandmother

“After surviving the atomic bomb in Hiroshima at age 12, my Japanese grandmother spent the rest of her school days helping to rebuild the city. This left her with no options for continuing her education and no skills beyond menial labor. Her eyes tell the story of shame and regret that many individuals who miss out on a basic education carry for the rest of their lives. I can't turn back time and I can't take my grandmother's pain away, but I can make sure that future generations can find hope and resilience through education, despite the atrocities of war. In Japanese culture, paper cranes are a symbol of hope after hardship. It is said that if you give 1,000 paper cranes, your wish will come true. In memory of my grandmother and to all who are part of a lost generation, my wish is that all children can claim their right to education during times of war, so that they can have the  liberties that my grandmother and millions of others lacked.”

                                                   - Janae, Aliim Founder, USA

The Burden Of Refugees

“I first witnessed the reality of displaced communities a few years ago, during an internship at the National Agency for Support and Integration of Refugees (ANAIR) in Mauritania. The agency was in charge of repatriating nationals who had  been unlawfully expelled from the country during 20 years. There, I realized the burden refugees face after years away. Rebuilding communities, starting new lives, reviving the economy are no easy tasks, especially in a context of poverty or in post-conflicts settings. This experience triggered my commitment to helping refugees in their host countries to keep living, learning, evolving, so that when the day comes and they can finally go home, they are better equipped to face the huge challenges awaiting them.”    

                                                        - Safia, Refugee Counselor, Germany


FAQs

Q. Where are you headquartered?

A. Aliim Corporation, known as “Aliim”, is a 501(c)(3) non-profit, headquartered in New York, with team members located in Lebanon, Germany, the Netherlands, Mexico, Uganda, and the U.S.

Q. What does Aliim mean?

A. Aliim is a derivative of the noun “تعلم”  which means “learning, education, study” in Arabic.

Q. What kind of smartphone is required to use your learning platform?

A. Any Android based smartphone.

Q. What if the youth don’t have access to a smartphone?

A. Our field survey showed that most of them do. However, we intend to equip each student with a basic smartphone for our pilot program.

Q. How will your program keep tabs on the children who receive the smartphones? Will they receive assignments and ongoing correspondence from teachers, or is all coursework completed through the app?

A. We will keep track of each student’s progress through the classroom management platform accessed through an app on the smartphone, which notifies the student, their parents, mentors, and Aliim program supervisors of important learning indicators. When a student is struggling with a specific concept, the student’s assigned mentor will reach out to the student directly through the app to provide support. Supplemental learning material will also be provided through the app. If needed, the student’s mentor may go over the supplemental learning materials with the student, providing further explanations over a video conferencing platform like Skype. If problems persist, Aliim supervisors will meet with the student and their parents in person to discuss what additional support the student needs to progress through the program.

Q. Won’t access to electricity and Internet be an obstacle for children’s participation?  

A. 3G/4G coverage is sufficient in most parts of the region. Access to electricity however can be difficult in some remote areas or overcrowded camps. To avoid any inconvenience and make sure our students can effectively participate in the program, we will equip them with solar chargers. In case of restrained access to internet, we always have the possibility to use wifi hotspots in community centers or other locations parents and children find suitable.

Q. How long will the pilot program run?

A. The pilot program will run for a normal school year, 9 months.

Q. Will courses be taught in English or Arabic?

A. Courses will be in Arabic, except for the English module which will be both Arabic and English. In phase two of our program, we will include an English translation of each lesson and activity. This will help students learn English faster as it provides more exposure to the language.

Q. How much will your crowdfunding effort aim to raise?

A. $75,000 which will provide the Smartphone Schools program to 250 Syrian refugee youth ages 12 to 15 for one school year.

Q. What other refugee populations do you hope to reach next?

A. The pilot program is mainly targeted at refugee girls because we believe they are the most vulnerable, but we intend to include boys, as possible. We also hope to expand to reach more Syrian refugees in Jordan, Turkey, and Western Europe. We are also looking into how our mobile learning framework can help South Sudanese refugees.

Q. How big is your team?

A. We are a small team of 10 core people and a growing network of mentors and volunteers.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you want to contribute to our cause in other ways, you can! Help spread the word about our work and our campaign by clicking on the social sharing icons on the left sidebar.

You can also help in one easy step. Change your charity of choice on Amazon to Aliim Corporation. That way, whenever you shop, you donate! The price of the items don't change, the donations come out of Amazon's commission on the products you buy. Follow the link below to make this quick change right now!

CLICK HERE TO GO TO AMAZON NOW!

Thank you everyone for your help to get the Smartphone Schools Project off the ground, each share or small contribution counts!


Aliim’s 501(c)(3) Status for Tax Deduction Purposes

To verify our U.S. non-profit status, you can access our IRS 501(c)(3) determination letter by clicking here.


Featured Perk 

Yiğit Yazici Print "Blue"


Dimensions 60X60cm-80X80cm, Fine Art Print on Paper, 50 edition, 2014. 

In support of Syrian Refugees and Aliim's work, Yigit has donated this painting to our crowdfunding campaign so 100% of the funds will go directly to the Smartphone Schools Program. 




YIGIT YAZICI

"To express myself freely is the most important thing for me in life, and I've been doing that through art since I was 20. I'm determined to follow up this path I've chosen at a very young age, until the end of my life. I define my goal in life as acknowledging, composing and extending myself. The world of art serves me to reach this. My relation with the viewer makes my dreams and my life meaningful. If you ask me the meaning of my existence I would say awareness and creating. I accept myself as I am and I respect that. My greatest weapon in life is to embrace the unknown. My mission above all is knowing myself and to share my work with people. My admiration for nature gives me infinite energy and my nature helps me to hold on to life with joy. As I have always said, everything is the result of a choice we make.

And I chose to be happy."

- Yigit Yazici

To learn more about Yigit's recent works, including his new Exhibition in Miami, click here. Or to visit his website, click here.
story_txt:
Aliim
Aliim is a non-profit organization whose mission is to leverage technology and mentors to provide refugees and marginalized youth access to safe, quality, and relevant education.Smartphone Schools ProgramAliim’s Smartphone Schools Program is the first mobile learning program that aims to empower Syrian refugee youth living in the Levant or migrating to other regions of the world, to continue their education and access better economic opportunities through technology and a global network of mentors. We have developed a theoretical framework to contextualize our curriculum in order to better address the specific needs of Syrian refugees – with a focus on girls – and adapt to the resources available in a particular conflict-affected setting. Students can access the program's learning content through an application, with on-line and off-line functionality. If successful, our program model can also be tailored to other conflict or emergency contexts. We expect to later extended mobile learning programs to the MENA region, along with Africa and Asia, where the need for education is extensive. "App Provides Education For Migrants On The Move"On December 29, 2015 CNN's Alison Kosik interviewed Aliim's Founder & CEO, Janae Bushman live about this crowdfunding campaign and about our smartphone drive (see aliim.org for information about the drive). See the link below to watch the CNN video. "App Provides Education For Migrants On The Move""Technology and smartphones could help to educate refugees"On November 30, 2015 CNBC's Luke Graham, published about our innovative Smartphone Schools Program and the impact our program can have on refugees. See the link below to read the article.   "Technology and Smartphones Could Help to Educate Refugees"2.7 Million Syrian Out-Of-School ChildrenFollowing 4 years of conflict, more than 2.7 million Syrian children don’t have access to any kind of education. Many of them have missed out on 2 to 3 years of school and are now verging on becoming a lost generation.With each lost year of schooling, the chance that these youth will return to formal education greatly diminishes, leaving those who will eventually be responsible for rebuilding their country with little hope for a future.Girls Are Particularly at RiskWhile the rate of child and forced marriage was already significant in Syria before the war, it dramatically increased following the current crisis, excluding girls from the secondary school system and exposing them to dangerous early pregnancy or a higher risk of domestic violence. In Lebanon, 18% of Syrian girls, ages 15 to 18 are married (against 2% for boys).Many reports highlight the fact that girls are more likely to be kept at home as a consequence of security issues, especially sexual and gender-based violence, which are realities of the life in refugee camps. To learn more about the dramatic consequences of the Syrian crisis on girls, click here.Malala's VoiceThe Nobel Peace Prize winner, Malala Yousafzai, is especially an inspiration to us at Aliim. Malala recently built a school in Lebanon for Syrian refugee girls. We believe that mobile learning can extend the work of organizations like the Malala Fund, to bring education beyond the walls of the classroom and into the hands of refugee girls who cannot come to school. With permission from the Malala Foundation, we wanted to share a beautiful short film that lends Malala's voice to the urgency behind reaching out to refugee girls and the impact we all can have as we work towards including  more girls in formal or non-formal education. 

Education Is the Key

Education is more than a fundamental human right. It is essential to the exercise of all other human rights. By also providing youth with the right tools to understand the world they live in and empowering them to fully and positively take part in the society, education is crucial to achieving global goals. At Aliim, we believe that education is the key to a better world.In the specific context of the Syrian crisis, education can mitigate some of the risks that refugees face, especially girls. Safe learning environments can protect them from getting trapped in cheap labor or early marriage and empower them to stand for their rights.Our Plans for 2016Based on the results of a field survey we conducted in Lebanon and several recent publications on refugee educational needs, we have developed a theoretical framework to contextualize our curriculum in order to better address the specific needs of Syrian refugees – with a focus on girls – and adapt to the resources available in a particular conflict-affected setting.We are now seeking donations to launch the Smartphone Schools pilot program in Sidon and Akkar, Lebanon. Aliim will use 100 percent of the proceeds to develop out the program, including:1) Developing the program’s curriculum further and uploading it to the mobile learning platform;2) Provide students with basic smartphones ($40 each) and solar panels for charging, along with wifi and data plans;3) Staff salary on the ground in Lebanon to oversee the implementation of the program;4) Provide TOEFL tests for each student learning English; and5) Impact evaluations to ensure we are effectively meeting the program’s learning objectives.We can provide all this for just under $34 a month per student ($300 per student for a full school year), with a goal of serving 250 Syrian refugee children ages 12 to 16 (mainly girls) in the pilot program.What if we don’t reach our goal?Every dollar counts. We are currently looking for corporate partners and applying for grants and will keep up our fundraising efforts until the pilot program is launched.What if we exceed our goal?The more we bring in during this campaign, the more out-of-school students we we can reach and enroll into our program. $75,000 USD is the minimum to get started, which provide Smartphone Schools to 250 refugees for a full school year. Beyond the baseline goal, our stretch goal is $150,000, with which we can reach hundreds of additional refugee children. Learn More About Our Unique CurriculumOur Smartphone Schools Program is not only about giving out-of-school Syrian youth the chance to acquire crucial knowledge and encouraging them to study further. It aims at empowering the next generation of Syrians, especially girls, to have a positive impact on their new community within their country of asylum. It also prepares youth to become active contributors to both the local and global economy, and eventually participate in reconstructing Syria when the war is over.To reach these goals, and based on the results of our needs assessment, we designed our curriculum to include relevant skills, special learning features, and a series of innovative pedagogical tools to make our program unique.Our International Mentor NetworkOur Smartphone School program includes interaction with an international network of mentors who will accompany students throughout the nine months, giving them feedback and answering their questions. With mobile technology, our mentors can live anywhere in the world. We believe that mentoring is an essential aspect of the program. By giving youth the opportunity to obtain the support they need from people all around the world, we intend to create a real community, allowing them to get guidance even after they finish the program, and eventually opening them professional opportunities.Giving Children a VoiceIf we bring school to youth through technology, why not leverage this channel to give them a voice? Our blog “Voices of Peace” will be a platform for students and youth around the world to interact with each other and the global community by sharing poetry, essays, photography, and artwork.Our English ModuleBeyond limited spots for Syrian refugees in public schools, one of the main obstacle for Syrian youth to access education in their host countries is language. This is particularly the case in Lebanon, where education is taught in English and French. Our English curriculum will be designed to prepare students to TOEFL certification in order to facilitate their integration into formal schools. Beyond this aspect, English skills can make a huge difference for Syrian refugees who continue their journey in other countries, especially in Europe, where the majority arrives with little other language skills than Arabic, experiencing crippling communication issues.Our Citizenship ModuleThe goal of Aliim’s Citizenship curriculum is to empower students to engage with their new community in a positive way, enjoy and exercise their rights, and to think critically about their surrounding and society, looking to credible information sources to help them in this process. We are convinced that our students could have an even greater impact on their environment by diffusing these values.Besides lessons on basic Human Rights, the curriculum will include a special focus on tolerance and gender equality. We want girls to be aware of their rights and boys to stand up for them.The citizenship curriculum will also provide students concrete information on local institutions and organizations in order for them to know who to turn to in case they encounter specific difficulties.Our Entrepreneurship ModuleThe Entrepreneurship curriculum will present foundational business concepts with a special focus on innovation and solution finding. More than knowledge, this curriculum aims at inspiring our students to dare dream of a better tomorrow and  what we would like to provide them with the Entrepreneurship module.Get to Know Aliim's TeamIn a mobilized world, we believe that it is possible to fulfill every child’s right to education.Aliim’s team is a global network of individuals who share a passion for technology and the ways we can leverage it to achieve global goals. We are committed to helping marginalized youth to reach their full potential by providing them access to education and empowering them to fully take part in the society.From the United States to Lebanon, Germany, Mexico, the Netherlands, and Uganda, Aliim’s team’s member combine over 40 years of experience in  teaching, curriculum design, finance, marketing, management consulting, human rights law, e-commerce, engineering, programming, strategic planning, evaluations, data analysis, fundraising, and program implementation.Local PartnersAliim works with local partners including, the Center for Applied Research in Education (CARE) at the University of Notre Dame, Louaize. CARE and our other partners help us connect the needs of the local communities with our mobile learning curriculum to ensure we provide the most relevant and applicable skills in a way that follows international education in emergency guidelines.What Motivates UsEchoes From a Lost Generation, Janae’s Grandmother“After surviving the atomic bomb in Hiroshima at age 12, my Japanese grandmother spent the rest of her school days helping to rebuild the city. This left her with no options for continuing her education and no skills beyond menial labor. Her eyes tell the story of shame and regret that many individuals who miss out on a basic education carry for the rest of their lives. I can't turn back time and I can't take my grandmother's pain away, but I can make sure that future generations can find hope and resilience through education, despite the atrocities of war. In Japanese culture, paper cranes are a symbol of hope after hardship. It is said that if you give 1,000 paper cranes, your wish will come true. In memory of my grandmother and to all who are part of a lost generation, my wish is that all children can claim their right to education during times of war, so that they can have the  liberties that my grandmother and millions of others lacked.”                                                   - Janae, Aliim Founder, USA

The Burden Of Refugees
“I first witnessed the reality of displaced communities a few years ago, during an internship at the National Agency for Support and Integration of Refugees (ANAIR) in Mauritania. The agency was in charge of repatriating nationals who had  been unlawfully expelled from the country during 20 years. There, I realized the burden refugees face after years away. Rebuilding communities, starting new lives, reviving the economy are no easy tasks, especially in a context of poverty or in post-conflicts settings. This experience triggered my commitment to helping refugees in their host countries to keep living, learning, evolving, so that when the day comes and they can finally go home, they are better equipped to face the huge challenges awaiting them.”    
                                                        - Safia, Refugee Counselor, Germany
FAQsQ. Where are you headquartered?A. Aliim Corporation, known as “Aliim”, is a 501(c)(3) non-profit, headquartered in New York, with team members located in Lebanon, Germany, the Netherlands, Mexico, Uganda, and the U.S.Q. What does Aliim mean?A. Aliim is a derivative of the noun “تعلم”  which means “learning, education, study” in Arabic.Q. What kind of smartphone is required to use your learning platform?A. Any Android based smartphone.Q. What if the youth don’t have access to a smartphone?A. Our field survey showed that most of them do. However, we intend to equip each student with a basic smartphone for our pilot program.Q. How will your program keep tabs on the children who receive the smartphones? Will they receive assignments and ongoing correspondence from teachers, or is all coursework completed through the app?A. We will keep track of each student’s progress through the classroom management platform accessed through an app on the smartphone, which notifies the student, their parents, mentors, and Aliim program supervisors of important learning indicators. When a student is struggling with a specific concept, the student’s assigned mentor will reach out to the student directly through the app to provide support. Supplemental learning material will also be provided through the app. If needed, the student’s mentor may go over the supplemental learning materials with the student, providing further explanations over a video conferencing platform like Skype. If problems persist, Aliim supervisors will meet with the student and their parents in person to discuss what additional support the student needs to progress through the program.Q. Won’t access to electricity and Internet be an obstacle for children’s participation?  A. 3G/4G coverage is sufficient in most parts of the region. Access to electricity however can be difficult in some remote areas or overcrowded camps. To avoid any inconvenience and make sure our students can effectively participate in the program, we will equip them with solar chargers. In case of restrained access to internet, we always have the possibility to use wifi hotspots in community centers or other locations parents and children find suitable.Q. How long will the pilot program run?A. The pilot program will run for a normal school year, 9 months.Q. Will courses be taught in English or Arabic?A. Courses will be in Arabic, except for the English module which will be both Arabic and English. In phase two of our program, we will include an English translation of each lesson and activity. This will help students learn English faster as it provides more exposure to the language.Q. How much will your crowdfunding effort aim to raise?A. $75,000 which will provide the Smartphone Schools program to 250 Syrian refugee youth ages 12 to 15 for one school year.Q. What other refugee populations do you hope to reach next?A. The pilot program is mainly targeted at refugee girls because we believe they are the most vulnerable, but we intend to include boys, as possible. We also hope to expand to reach more Syrian refugees in Jordan, Turkey, and Western Europe. We are also looking into how our mobile learning framework can help South Sudanese refugees.Q. How big is your team?A. We are a small team of 10 core people and a growing network of mentors and volunteers.Other Ways You Can HelpIf you want to contribute to our cause in other ways, you can! Help spread the word about our work and our campaign by clicking on the social sharing icons on the left sidebar.You can also help in one easy step. Change your charity of choice on Amazon to Aliim Corporation. That way, whenever you shop, you donate! The price of the items don't change, the donations come out of Amazon's commission on the products you buy. Follow the link below to make this quick change right now!CLICK HERE TO GO TO AMAZON NOW!Thank you everyone for your help to get the Smartphone Schools Project off the ground, each share or small contribution counts!Aliim’s 501(c)(3) Status for Tax Deduction PurposesTo verify our U.S. non-profit status, you can access our IRS 501(c)(3) determination letter by clicking here.Featured Perk Yiğit Yazici Print "Blue"

I'm determined to follow up this path I've chosen at a very young age, until the end of my life. I define my goal in life as acknowledging, composing and extending myself. The world of art serves me to reach this. My relation with the viewer makes my dreams and my life meaningful. If you ask me the meaning of my existence I would say awareness and creating. I accept myself as I am and I respect that. story:
Short Summary

Tampa Archery School will be getting a permanent home with a 20-yard indoor range and more room to do cool stuff! 

What does this mean for you? Well, first off it means we will be able to have class at least 4 days a week, as well as have open practice times, internal competitions, themed events and maybe even a league. Additionally, we can bring in bow maintenance and tuning gear to provide us you (if you're up to it) a place to fletch and fix arrows, fine tune your bow and more!

Pretty exciting...I know...

Why I Started This Indiegogo Account

This opportunity has sort of dropped into our laps. And, we have been saving for this possibility for a while, we're going to need help (financial and otherwise) to make the space live up to it's potential.

It's no secret that your class tuition keeps Tampa Archery School at a self-sustaining level. We're not a non-profit, but we might as well be. Every penny you pay into the program comes back in the form of training, targets, events like the Halloween party, repairs, tuning gear and other stuff...well, after things like insurance, rent, certifications, taxes and all that jazz is paid. 

So, Mark and I are turning to you...our students and friends...and asking you to make a modest investment in the future of the School. I don't expect us to reach the full $8K goal I've set, but any and all investment made will go into the creation of your new Tampa Archery School.

The Impact

Yes, we are looking to raise a large sum of money. So, let me show what that money will go toward:

  • Space Deposit.............................................................$3,000
  • Turn-on of utilities.......................................................$1,200
  • Portable AC units........................................................$1,500
  • Paint and flooring........................................................$1,500
  • Wood & Building Supplies..........................................$1000
  • Additional targets.......................................................$600
  • General repair and cleaning.......................................$500
  • Bow press....................................................................$400
  • Target Stands..............................................................$200
  • Indoor 3D target mounts............................................$200
  • Additional arrow nets.................................................$600
  • Bow racks....................................................................$24
  • Fletching jigs...............................................................$100
  • String-building jig.......................................................$100
I know it's more than $8K...but you see what we're looking at, right? Some of these items we probably won't have by the "grand opening." But, we sure as all hell will try...because...well...archery! 
Every penny we raise here will go toward one or more of these expenses and help make Tampa Archery School a place we can all be proud of.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some of you may want to help but cannot contribute financially. We totally get it and completely understand. But, that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Help us get the word out and make some noise (in person and on social media) about what we're trying to do.
  • Volunteer to help with the cleaning, painting and build-out of the new place.
  • Make a donation of supplies (Paint, astroturf, etc.) or gear (bow press, circular saw, benches or seating, etc.) if you have it.
  • Tell friends, family and just about anyone else you talk to about how cool archery is to do and how great Tampa Archery School is.

We thank you ahead of time. This is an exciting step we take toward being the training and recreation facility we believe you deserve!

story:
Short Summary

During the summer of 2014, I had this amazing opportunity to visit Cape Town, South Africa for the first time. My sister and I decided to  volunteer at the Desmond Tutu HIV AIDS Youth Center.  Before we went there, I  didn't quite know what to expect or what exactly we were supposed to be doing. The first couple of days were bit awkward as we were new, from another country and did not know the youth/kids and the staff that were there. We did many odd jobs around the center; we helped out in the technology room, the vegetable garden, and kitchen. But my favorite part of the day was that once the work was finished, I got to play soccer with all the kids for hours together! They loved the game and played with no shoes or gear in the dirt courtyard with a big smile on their faces.  The kids at the Center were from HIV AIDS affected families from the Masiphumelele Township, a shanty town next door.  They all came from very poor families. The effects of the disease was all around us, and it was very sad. But you would never guess that if you met these kids. In spite of their circumstances, these were some of the happiest kids I have ever met. It made me realize how much I had to be thankful for, living in USA and the environment  I was growing up in and everything I had.  Even though the kids and I were from completely different worlds, the one thing we had in common was our passion for soccer!!  Soccer instantly "connected" me to the kids, and we became friends!  As I was finishing my volunteer project, I gave my green soccer ball to the kids. Just that one simple act made the kids so ecstatic and happy. It really touched me. I decided I need to do more for them.  They deserve so much more than what they have. I am going back this summer to volunteer there, and I want take funds to buy soccer balls and gear for all of them! So I need to raise funds!

Please watch the video above, and I would be very thankful if you could support me 

What We Need

There are close to about 100 kids that the Youth Center supports. My goal is to get each one a pair of soccer shoes (cleats), socks and clothes. The cost is approximately $ 100 per kid. So 100 x $100.00 is about $10,000.  Any funds left over will be used to buy balls and soccer equipment.  My goal is to raise $10K for this initiative.

The Impact

These kids don't have much going for them. The Youth Center is one place where they come to play and spend some time being happy in an otherwise depressing environment. If a simple soccer ball could lift their spirits, imagine what some spanking new soccer gear will do for them!

I wish I could offer some incentives for your contributions, but that would only take away from what I can give these kids. 

Other Ways You Can Help

I sincerely hope to achieve my fund raising goal of 11K (including costs and fees). If I'm able to raise more than that, I'd like to convert their gravel patch into a usable soccer field. So please continue to donate even if the initial target has been reached. 

Thank you very much!

Nikhil Swaminathan -Junior at Walter Johnson High School, Bethesda MD USA.

story:
OUR STORY

Mission

The Maama Omwana Project strives to improve the well-being of mothers and infants in Uganda through culturally appropriate eduactional programs. We imagine a world where mothers are educated, supported, empowered and able to give birth feeling confident and informed.

Values

Through collaborative work with women in Uganda, we share a core value of relationship building. Our work and relationships are longstanding and deeply rooted at the community level. We value the importance of working in coalition with women in order to be successful in our mission.

History

Maama Omwana began with a vision to promote prenatal education as a tool for improving maternal and infant health in Uganda and has evolved into a collaborative community based program that promotes informed birth for the well-being of families, women's rights, and HIV awareness. Founded by Sarah Van Wyck, a birth and postpartum doula, gender studies major at the University of British Columbia, and passionate women's rights advocate, our first program began in 2014.

After a trip to Uganda in 2014 volunteering as a prenatal educator and doula, Sarah connected with a local organization who played a key role in organizing over 200 women to learn. She met some amazing people who were passionate about building their community and who invited her to organize a continual program for mothers and infants.

Our Program - Maama Class Uganda

Maama Class Uganda is an initiative to connect childbearing women in Uganda through education. Through the employment of a local Ugandan prenatal educator, Maama Class Uganda offers a culturally appropriate avenue to learning prenatal education, education on women’s rights, HIV education, partner communication, and family planning techniques.

Why is Prenatal Education Important?

Access to maternal health in Uganda is limited. Government hospitals are overcrowded and private clinics are costly. Prenatal education is important because it gives women the education they need to make informed decisions about their preganany, birth, postpartum, and their overall health.

What is a Maama Birthing Kit and why are they important?

A Maama Kit  provides a lifeline for some mothers. Some hospitals and clinics have little resources for women giving birth; if we can equip women and their care providers with the most basic tools for infant delivery, it could significantly change the outcome of her birth.

According to PACE Uganda, A CDK (Clean Delivery Kit) provides the necessary tools and instructions to achieve the World Health Organization's "Five Cleans" throughout the birthing process and reduce maternal and child mortality. It can help to prevent infections and death of the mother and baby by preventing tetanus, sepsis, HIV, infant eye infection.


A CDK contains; a plastic sheet, soap, 2 pairs of surgical gloves, cotton wool, cord ties, a surgical blade and a new child growth and postnatal card.

What are Cycle Beads and why are they important?

Cycle Beads are a form of family planning that is acceptable to women whose faith does not permit medical contraceptives. They are also important for women who have limited access to medical care and prescriptions. They are a tool that gives women the education and the opportunity to plan their reproductive lives.

How you can help

We imagine a world where mothers are supported, empowered and able to give birth feeling confident and informed. Your generous donation will allow us to continue working towards this vision.

Your general donation will allow Maama Omwana to make the best use of your funds by contributing to the project elements most in need. It will be re-invested into the community and work towards the empowerment and education of birthing women through our Maama Class Program and the development of future programs.

Check out the Maama Omwana website to see examples of how far your donations can go! www.maamaomwana.org

story:
FACT: Indigenous people of Canada have, without question, the numbers to change the political landscape of our province when we exercise our right to vote.

Summary

Indigenous Vote Sask is a provincial, non-partisan effort to mobilize the First Nations, Métis and Inuit vote in Saskatchewan:

  • This initiative was the result of the changes to voter ID requirements in the "Fair Elections Act" which would impact our most vulnerable peoples in Sask. 
  • We have focused our efforts on developing urban voting hubs where volunteers will work to motivate and assist in reducing barriers in access to vote in the Federal Election 2015.
  • This campaign can help us reach First Nations and rural communities to do community outreach for voter registration, provide general voting information and political strategy information for Electoral Districts.
  • We know statistically that if Indigenous people wanted to change the political landscape in our province, voting as one - as a bloc, can be a successful strategy in key ridings.

With 104,000 Indigenous voters in Saskatchewan we need your help!

  • Put simply, the more funds we obtain, the more outreach to Indigenous communities and getting folks the proper ID they need to vote is possible.
  • We will also need funds to help get out the vote for Elections day.  Transportation to the polls being one huge barrier in access that we hope to assist in Urban hubs!
  • If we do not reach our goal, the funds still go towards community outreach and assisting in ID clinics in the province of Saskatchewan.

The Impact

  • Keeping a non-partisan effort to get our people to the polls is necessary in building trust in a system that has not always been welcoming or supportive to Indigenous voters.  This is a grassroots  initiative for the people by the people.
  • Not one single volunteer will be paid nor will we accept funds from candidates or Federal parties.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot donate money, but want to help, there are many ways to get involved!

  • Volunteer to sit as a key member of one of the most important committees this year will bring! We currently have voter hubs in Saskatoon, Prince Albert and Regina and more to come.  If you cannot sit on a committee, you can volunteer at events where you have free time.

  • Organize and start a hub in your community and we will work hard to make sure to support you and provide a toolkit to get you started

  •  Share the Indigenous Vote page, events and encourage your friends, family and anyone who will listen to prepare to vote in the 2015 election.

story:
Here's my story:

My name is Seth. I am 21 years old, come from a small Minnesota town, and I am a student pilot. The problem is I don't come from a wealthy family. My parents have given me everything they have to help fund my schooling, but sadly that is not enough. 

I have completed my private pilot certificate and I am currently working on my commercial pilot certificate. It is very important that I finish school and get a job because if I don't I won't be able to pay off my loans, and if that happens my parents (cosigners) and I will lose everything. Every dollar that you donate will help.

I travel throughout the US logging hours of flight time. Though it's awesome to see all the new places, sometimes I am away from family and friends for months. 

What We Need:

Let's break it down for you:

  • I have over $100,000 in debt so far. 
  • It is impossible for me to receive any more loans, I have already tried.
  • Every single dollar I get will go towards paying off the loans.
  • Even if I don't reach my goal the funds will still be used to help pay for my loans.
  • If I receive more than my goal the funds will be used to help other pilots get started. It's not easy to become a pilot, and I know the struggle all too well.
  • Share my story! Nothing helps more than getting the word out! Thanks!

Here's an idea:

If I can manage to get this project funded and get on my feet, I can start a new non-profit campaign for other pilots struggling financially. I would be the voice of the 96% of student pilots that won't get a job but still have the debt.

Perks:

  1. $1    Thank you. Your name will appear on this campaign as a contributor.
  2. $5   Thank you. Your name will appear on this campaign as a contributor.
  3. $10 Personal thank you. I will send you a personal thank you card with a signed aerial picture from one of my flights. Don't worry, it won't be a boring picture.
  4. Every time you donate, I'll put your name on this campaign's page, and on my next non-profit campaign I am currently working on.

Risks & Challenges:

I have faced many challenges over the years, and I have always gotten through them with the help and support of my friends and families. Now I look to you for support. Only about 1 in 30 student pilots land a job right out of school, and I have a job lined up for me. Now I just need your help to pay for the hours of flying that are required to get the job.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute yourself, others may be able to. Please share this with friends and family.

story:
The Well-Trained Mind Montessori

My name is Jason Bruni and I am passionate about a lot of things but making sure children have the best education tops my list. Part of ensuring a child gets a good education is making sure the school they are at has the necessary tools to do so.

   

   While teachers are the biggest part of the equation, office equipment like desks, chairs, pencils, paper and especially a reliable office printer are key to success. Recently, I found out that the Montessori a friend of mine works at does not have a printer they can afford to use. This is an issue because of how the school operates. 

       The Well-Trained Mind Montessori consists of two educators and 30 students. They have a garden, pets (such as chickens), and tech/prepaid kids for more than just reading textbooks in the next grade; they help prepare them for real life. Believe it or not, it's a lot harder to help provide a good education without a working printer. It's very doable, don't get me wrong, but it requires the teachers to use their library area and the cards of all their friends (my friend asked for Christmas to have people donate their printing at the library so she could have packets to give the kids) to make it happen. I would like to believe I'm not the only one who finds that to be ridiculous....that's where you come in.

 

        I have found a printer that would work perfect for the school. It's a Xerox WorkCenter 6400x Color multifunction Printer. I'm sure you can tell by the name it isn't cheap, you're right. It costs $4400...yeah, that's expensive. Here is the thing though, the toner cartridges can print 44,000 pages before they are done and it costs $73 for a new 2-pack. What that means is a crazy low cost for the school to print from here on out! Every dollar raised over the total printer cost will be used to purchase extra supplies for the printer. If we exceed the $5k mark, the funds will go to other betterment projects for the school. This is a very achievable goal. If 500 people donated $10, we are there. $10 doesn't go very far these days. You can get a coffee and pastry from Starbucks, with current gas prices you could get 5-6 gallons of gas, or you could make a difference for a child.

        A Well -Trained Mind hasn't increased the cost to go to school there in years because it matters more to them to make sure everyone can go there who wants than it  does to make a profit. This Montessori is on the precipice of greatness, join me in helping them cross that line by making a donation today towards their new printer.

story:
A School for Hands-On Learning & Work Opportunities

The Next Frontier Academy is a one-of-a-kind school giving urban students a chance to succeed both in school and in the world beyond.

The school started in 2013 to provide a solution to the problems many urban students face.  The Next Frontier Academy had a simple question: What can we do to help them build a strong foundation and give them a chance to succeed after school?

The Next Frontier Academy:

  • is a non-profit community school for 7th to 12th graders in Akron, Ohio.

  • is committed to providing hands-on and project-based learning opportunities for students.  

  • achieves success through blended learning.

  • prepares our students to start a successful career, especially in the agriculture industry, where 22% of the jobs (over 400 types) in Ohio are.

  • helps students find, keep, and grow a career upon graduation.  

Invest in our future agriculture leaders today before their opportunity is gone.


The Next Frontier Academy believes in hands-on and project-based learning through:

  • one-on-one instruction and small class sizes

  • hands-on cooking and nutrition education from a chef through at an in-school kitchen

  • in-school hydroponics and soil planting labs to grow lettuce, kale, and wheatgrass

  • summer work program at a farm where students plant, harvest, and sell 250 dozen ears of corn

  • field trips to local greenhouses and businesses

Investing in our students is an investment in our future. Our students gain:

  • knowledge in the newest technological means to prevent future problems like the California drought.

  • the ability to grow healthy and green produce while keeping food costs down.

  • entrepreneurial skills and ideas to help move our world in a positive and healthy way.

These are the agriculture leaders of our future! Invest today before their opportunity is gone! 


Thanks to the following corporations for their generous investment of $1,000 or more!

             


How Donations Benefit Students

All donations create in-school opportunities for the daily benefit of our students. The Next Frontier Academy plans to generate $100,000 to install, build, and enhance several critical programs, such as:

  • Expand Hydroponics and Soil Laboratory - $30,000

  • Improve equipment in kitchen and improve cafeteria - $25,000

  • Upgrade classroom equipment for 21st-century instruction (SMART Boards, Projectors) - $8,000

  • Install desktop computer and laptop workstations in 4 classrooms - $25,000

  • Necessary daily building maintenance and improvements - $25,000

Donations will also provide opportunities for our students to:
  • Visit Smithers & Oasis greenhouses to see how the growing process works from the beginning
  • Visit The Mustard Seed Market to understand the importance of chemical-free foods and the retail process after the food is grown.

These visits, as well as others, provide real-world experience for students to both expand their knowledge and prepare them for their future.

These are benefits that urban students would not have without The Next Frontier Academy and you!


The Challenges We Face

As an urban school, we face daily challenges and social obstacles such as:

  • Students coming from a broken family structure

  • Many students coming from low-income homes

  • Many students who have fallen behind educationally

  • Urban societal norms

  • The urban stigma against education from a youth perspective

  • Failing these students by not meeting their needs


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share The Next Frontier Academy’s story with others

  • Contact the school for volunteer opportunities

  • Share this Indiegogo campaign with your friends and contacts


Your support helps build a strong foundation for The Next Frontier Academy students.


Thanks to the following corporations for their generous investment of $500 or more!

        

Thanks to the following corporations for their generous investment of time, and product or services!
