story:
1. This campaign is important to me because  I am concerned about the alarming dropout rate in the country in St. Vincent and the Grenadines and the Caribbean. I am doing volunteer work in  St. Vincent and the Grenadines  in the area of education. I have ran summer programs here for  four years. I was aware during my work that many children were not reading on grade level. I worked with many of them one on one. I noticed remarkable improvement.  I  have also produced educational television programs on the local station. I lacked funding to keep it up on a regular basis. I was watching television and I heard about the alarming dropout rate here. I did research in the St. Vincent and Grenadines Educational Statistical Digest 2013 published by the Ministry of Education. There was a total of 235 dropping out of primary school.1,296 out of secondary school ,224 were only in Form 1. That is an age of 12 years old!Kindergarten had 33. Compulsory education is from 4-16.My name Christopher Blackman and I am all familiar with these islands as I am greatly involved in volunteer work here in the schools.I am proud that I produced a children television program  that was appreciated by the children and their parents.When you think of the Caribbean Island, you may picture lush,white beaches,idyllic scenery of turquoise waters,and a true tropical paradise.Many people visit these small islands in the Caribbean to escape a stressful and hectic lifestyle,all to find amazement and relaxation as they explore colorful coral reefs by scuba diving and sail on the calm waters. However,for the people that make their lives there,the picture is different.St Vincent and the Grenadines house approximately 115,000 friendly people. Many of the families in the villages are unemployed and living in poverty. The island has reliable electricity,telephones and water;however many of the residents cannot afford electricity , water and telephone service.They depend on government-supplied public showers and water spigots. One-fourth of the population comprises children ages 1-14 years.Education is free until secondary school.Due to the extreme economic conditions many families face poverty,education is placed behind the need for the children to work on the farms.Parents or guardians cannot afford books,supplies, transportation and food. As a result,unemployment is very high,and many children and teenagers resort to illegal activities and are ultimately locked up in jail. It is not like these children do not want an education. Poverty prevents them.There has been a rise in pregnancy. Children having children. Many families are migrating with children who are below average in their schoolwork.Education is the one key to getting out of poverty. I want to use the power of television to offer educational programs. The goal is to have a television program that will be available to children and their parents.I have done this in the past. It was a success. The lack of funding forced me to discontinue. Many homes do not have computers.
  2.  Education can help empower and is the most influential tool for any society to thrive.You should already see the enormous value of what I am trying to do here. I'd like to serve as an inspiration for other entrepreneurs and meaningful social causes to get out there and release their innovations to the world through the crowdfunding model. We know a lot of people who needs a solution like this,so tell your friends to contribute so we can promote it to the world. Sharing this campaign on your social media profile is just as valuable as an actual financial pledge.


Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.
story_txt:
This campaign is important to me because  I am concerned about the alarming dropout rate in the country in St. Vincent and the Grenadines and the Caribbean. I am doing volunteer work in  St. Vincent and the Grenadines  in the area of education. I have ran summer programs here for  four years. I was aware during my work that many children were not reading on grade level. I worked with many of them one on one. I noticed remarkable improvement.  I  have also produced educational television programs on the local station. I lacked funding to keep it up on a regular basis. I was watching television and I heard about the alarming dropout rate here. I did research in the St. Vincent and Grenadines Educational Statistical Digest 2013 published by the Ministry of Education. There was a total of 235 dropping out of primary school.1,296 out of secondary school ,224 were only in Form 1. That is an age of 12 years old!Kindergarten had 33. Compulsory education is from 4-16.My name Christopher Blackman and I am all familiar with these islands as I am greatly involved in volunteer work here in the schools.I am proud that I produced a children television program  that was appreciated by the children and their parents.When you think of the Caribbean Island, you may picture lush,white beaches,idyllic scenery of turquoise waters,and a true tropical paradise.Many people visit these small islands in the Caribbean to escape a stressful and hectic lifestyle,all to find amazement and relaxation as they explore colorful coral reefs by scuba diving and sail on the calm waters. However,for the people that make their lives there,the picture is different.St Vincent and the Grenadines house approximately 115,000 friendly people. Many of the families in the villages are unemployed and living in poverty. The island has reliable electricity,telephones and water;however many of the residents cannot afford electricity , water and telephone service.They depend on government-supplied public showers and water spigots. One-fourth of the population comprises children ages 1-14 years.Education is free until secondary school.Due to the extreme economic conditions many families face poverty,education is placed behind the need for the children to work on the farms.Parents or guardians cannot afford books,supplies, transportation and food. As a result,unemployment is very high,and many children and teenagers resort to illegal activities and are ultimately locked up in jail. It is not like these children do not want an education. Poverty prevents them.There has been a rise in pregnancy. Children having children. Many families are migrating with children who are below average in their schoolwork.Education is the one key to getting out of poverty. I want to use the power of television to offer educational programs. The goal is to have a television program that will be available to children and their parents.I have done this in the past. It was a success. The lack of funding forced me to discontinue. Many homes do not have computers.

 Education can help empower and is the most influential tool for any society to thrive.You should already see the enormous value of what I am trying to do here. I'd like to serve as an inspiration for other entrepreneurs and meaningful social causes to get out there and release their innovations to the world through the crowdfunding model. We know a lot of people who needs a solution like this,so tell your friends to contribute so we can promote it to the world. Sharing this campaign on your social media profile is just as valuable as an actual financial pledge.

 Short Summary Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:  Introduce yourself and your background. Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you. Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.  Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?   What We Need & What You Get Break it down for folks in more detail:  Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.  Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited! Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.    The Impact Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:  Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world. Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one). Make it real for people and build trust.    Risks & Challenges  People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.  Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles. Describe your plan for solving these challenges.    Other Ways You Can Help Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:  Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign. Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!   And that's all there is to it.

story:
Give Central Falls students the best bike infrastructure possible

In cities like Portland, Oregon, Bike-to-School Day is everyday. Why not in Rhode Island, the U.S.' smallest and second densest state?

Bike-to-School Day is focused on raising funds for Central Falls students.

Central Falls is a dense city where you can find everything within a square mile. We'd like to help our students arrive safe, happy, and ready to learn. by bike. 

What We Need & What You Get

Calcutt Middle School is raising money, one-third of which will go to bike racks for the school, and two-thirds of which will go to safe-routes-to-school biking improvements in Central Falls.
For just $1 you can enter our Frog & Toad raffle, and get a chance to win $100 in store credit.
For $5 you get three chances to win Radia Herbs tea, a $7 value.
At the $20 level you enter to win either $25 in credit to Garden Grille restaurant, $50 credit to Cluck! gardening supply store, or fives chances to win a Cleverhoods rain fender for your bike, a $20 value.
Our highest donor will win $100 in credit from Dash Bicycles, and is still eligible to win other prizes.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute money, we'd also like to get your support.

  • If you are a parent, ride to school with one of your kids!
  • If you have a social network (who doesn't?), share this with other people!
  • Every bit of help matters. Thanks for helping Central Falls be a better place!

At the $20 level you enter to win either $25 in credit to Garden Grille restaurant, $50 credit to Cluck! gardening supply store, or fives chances to win a Cleverhoods rain fender for your bike, a $20 value.


Our highest donor will win $100 in credit from Dash Bicycles, and is still eligible to win other prizes.

If you have a social network (who doesn't?), share this with other people!
Every bit of help matters. Thanks for helping Central Falls be a better place!

story:
This is a different kind of fundraiser campaign! 


After exploring all possible options to pay for graduate school, I've come to the realization that I need to crowd source a student loan. Yes, you read it right...I'm hoping to source a student loan from YOU! This means that every donation will be PAID BACK IN FULL upon graduation.
My passion has been to end maternal mortality in Kenya and Africa as a whole. To do so, I need to get my masters. Our world needs trailblazers and I believe I'm one of them. Your contribution is seriously needed in order for me to achieve this mile stone: I cannot do this without your help. 
I will not only pay you back but I'll also put my public health expertise at your disposal when you need it. Grant writing for projects, evaluating a health intervention program...you name it! If it's global health, I'm here to help you. For an in-depth look at my skills, check out my LinkedIn profile here.

Part of the Renaissance Scholars Program, graduating class of 2014 at the University of Rochester, NY.


The $20,000 I'm raising is geared towards paying the tuition fees for the two years that I'll be part of the EuroPubHealth program (which is approx. € 18,000 since it's paid to the European consortium). Initially, I had applied for an Erasmus+ scholarship which would have covered this and more but got placed on the reserve list which meant that unless someone opted out of the scholarship, I only had one option left: to join the program as a self-funded student. 
Opting not to wait for someone to drop out, I started searching for other options. My first avenue was to look into student loans available to Kenyan students studying abroad. I was really hopeful that I was going to find something that would work...but boy, was I disappointed. To start, international banks required that I have a citizen or resident co-signer which is not a possibility for me. And second, Kenyan banks offered no student loans with flexible payment options such as post graduation payments and/or grace period. 

So what does this mean for me?
It means that I'm responsible for covering the tuition, living expenses, visa fees, airfare and health insurance from my savings. Fortunately, having worked part-time during my undergraduate, I have saved around $ 7,000 which can cover my living expenses for the first year as well as the visa fees, airfare and health insurance.The money I'm fundraising is for paying the tuition and securing my spot on the program. By doing so, I'll ensure that I have no stress of missing classes and can focus on studying and working part-time to save up to cover my living expenses for the second year. 

I know you're wondering, why is this opportunity so important? Here's why....
1. Out of hundreds of applications, I was among the approx. 20 successful candidates chosen to join the EuroPubHealth class of 2015-2017 which is part of the Erasmus+ program of the European Union. This highly competitive program offers a two year joint double public health masters program split between the University of Sheffield in the UK and the University of Copenhagen in Denmark.
Ultimately, by the time I graduate, I'll have strong credentials to start my career working on projects that matter to me. Being young as I am, I'll have the opportunity to be a strong voice within the healthcare sector in my country working on projects that will save lives of women and children. 
Additionally, the knowledge, networks and mentorship I will get throughout the program will go a long way in helping me launch a maternal health project I have been working on this past year. Hopefully this will mean that the pilot program could be launched by the summer of 2017!  

2. Coming from a single parent lower-middle-class family in Kenya, this is a major achievement for me. My journey to this point has been one full of challenges as well as unforeseen blessings. Both my high school education in Kenya and undergraduate education in the US have been made possible through a combination of merit and need based scholarships (Jomo Kenyatta Foundation Scholarships and The Renaissance & Global Scholarship), without which I wouldn't have made it this far. 
Although I'm the last born in my family, I'm the first to attend a 4-year college and will be the first to earn a masters. Moreover,this opportunity will help me inspire and motivate other girls who dare to dream big.

My four years at the University or Rochester, NY were the most amazing and most formative years of my life. I got to make lifetime friends, meet amazing mentors and support my family back home by balancing pursuing a double major in psychology and public health while working 15 hours a week. When I finally graduated, it was one of the proudest moments of my life.


Finally, how will your contribution impact the future? 
Glad you asked :) 
These two years of graduate education will prepare me professionally for a career focused on improving maternal health outcomes in Kenya and Africa as a whole. 
Currently, 99% of all maternal deaths occur in the developing world. In the developing world, 1 in 39 woman will face the risk of death due to pregnancy and birth complications yet in the developed world only 1 in 1600 face the same risk. 
Unfortunately, this is the sad reality of motherhood for poor women in my country. My experience working in Mukuru slums on the outskirts of Nairobi really put into perspective how important it is for me to pursue graduate studies to improve my impact in this field. 
This stark disparity is the source of my drive and commitment to improving maternal health in my country and my continent. I'm working for a future where motherhood is safe for all.


THANK YOU!
I hope that you join me on this journey towards achieving my dream. This is one of the most life defining opportunities I have gotten and I will not be able to grab it without your help.


With gratitude,
Sarah :)

story:
An Oasis of Hope for Sierra Leone's Deaf Children

The Ebert Kakua School for the Deaf on the outskirts of Sierra Leone's second largest city is the only government-certified school outside Freetown. In a country wracked with poverty (and recently rocked by the Ebola outbreak), the disabled were particularly hard hit. But during the time schools were closed due to the outbreak, the Ebert-Kakua school was not idle.

Using their own funds as well as grants from German and Spanish NGOs, the staff has expanded the campus to include a dormitory and community hall.

A residential program was started because it's dangerous for deaf students to cross all the busy streets to get to school (in the past few years there have been multiple injuries to deaf students and one fatality).  In addition, the entire country of Sierra Leone has only 3 official schools serving the entire country's deaf population. As a result, many students must travel up to three hours on foot or by bus to attend classes. By living at the school, attendance and learning as well as health improves because students are guaranteed regular meals in a caring, independence-promoting environment.

With schools reopening, the Ebert Kakua school needs to kit out its dorm and classrooms for returning students, especially first-ever resident students.

  • I've been supporting and visiting the school for over 6 years (even started a nonprofit, Deeper Missions, to help schools like this in Africa); I am amazed by the work being done and the lives transformed even in the most trying of environments.
  • This campaign helps keep the school on an exciting trajectory of growth and success for the students by filling the dorm with needed furniture, feeding the students and hiring caring "aunties" for a year and expanding the school's solar energy (yes, all that for just $40K!)

What We Need & What You Get

Here's a breakdown of what it will take to jumpstart school operations:

  • Electricity (the section of the city where the school is located has NO electrical infrastructure)--add to the 2Kw solar power system already there so every room on campus has power: $20K
  • Salaries for four aunties (as they are called) overseeing the students and dormitory, $12K
  • Furniture, school and vocational training supplies $3K
  • $5K will feed residential and day students as well as aunties for a year(!)

Perks 

  • Contributors will receive special hand-made gifts from grateful students as well as photos showing all the great work made possible because of you!
If our goal isn't met, the school will scale back the project by hiring fewer aunties and purchasing less furniture for fewer residential children.

The Impact

Your contribution isn't about putting stuff into school buildings, it's about helping radically transform the lives of children and young adults with hearing disabilities--supporting the chance for a better life for students already living under tough conditions:

  • Over 100 deaf students and young adults will continue to have the opportunity of an education, vocational and life-skills training helping them build a dignified and satisfying life
  • In 2013 I helped bring a solar electricity system to the school to power classrooms; the spare electricity was used to start a small cellphone charging service which now brings in enough funds monthly to pay one teacher's salary
  • I travel to the school regularly so I know this is the real deal

Risks & Challenges

Of course this campaign is launched before the Ebola outbreak is fully passed; while the Bo area has been Ebola-free for months, the risk exists that the projects will be delayed if there are continued flare-ups. Other than that, because of my close, long-standing relationship with the school and annual travel there, the risk to project success is minimized.

Other Ways You Can Help

Contribute or not, here's how you can help:

  • SHARE! Get the word out tell your friends and colleagues this awesome story
  • Along with all your social and professional network apps/sites, you can also PLEASE use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank You!

story:
Community Culture

 

Warribadee Community School is a unique independent school in regional Australia. We cater for disadvantaged Aboriginal children who would otherwise be failing in the public education system.  We teach traditional Aboriginal culture and arts alongside the usual English, Science and Mathematics curriculum.

 

 

There are 103 families living in our district and we want to ensure that all of their children have access to basic education.  There is no other school in the district and students otherwise face a two hour round trip to the nearest town.

 

 

What We Need

The school is set to open in 2016 but one thing is stopping us hiring a qualified teacher- we don't have any accommodation for them!  There is 23 houses in our village and we wish to make is 24.  There is currently no option for rent that is suitable for a family.

 

This is our village. It is very small. You can see the school building on the right.

 

We need a minimum of $5000 to supplement the funding we have in order to purchase a block of land in town.  Once we have a land base we can look at purchasing a kit home to go on it.  The full cost of a house and land package is over $200,000.

A three bedroom kit home like we'd like to build for our new teacher

 

 

Without accommodation we cannot possible entice an educator to our little village.  As we are an independent school with less than 30 students we are not eligible for enough government funding to cover our running costs.  And because our village is so small we simply do not have enough of a supporter base to come up with the funds ourselves.

 

Risks & Challenges

Our school has been 12 months in the making.  It has been a journey of love and longing from our Aboriginal Elders and community.  Our mothers and fathers, grandparents, aunts and uncles have all been working very hard to conform to the regulations of the Board of Education and the local Shire.  If we cannot obtain the services of a suitable teacher then all our hard work will be for nothing and our children will continue to fail the education system.

 

Please share our cause with all your friends and family.  Remember all you need is $1.

 

 

 

THANKYOU THANKYOU THANKYOU

story:
Growing up in a busy city like Boston, Massachusetts, it is often difficult for urban youth to make the connections between their daily lives and the natural world around them. Many are unfamiliar with the marine species living just under the surface of the Boston Harbor, or have never thought about how their usage of a plastic bag could affect a sea turtle swimming in the Atlantic Ocean.

That’s where “e” inc. comes in! “e” inc. – the environment science learning and action center is a community-based non-profit whose mission is to create scientifically-confident environmental citizens committed to understanding and protecting the Earth. In 2013-2014 alone, “e” inc. provided civics and science sessions to well over 6,000 children and teens in school year residencies and summer intensives at over 20 Greater Boston schools, community centers and other educational institutions.


Our Project

This year, “e” inc. is running its own Summer Science Discovery Program. The program will be based at the “e” inc. Discovery & Action Center in the Charlestown Navy Yard and is open to children ages 6-12. The program is comprised of two 1-week sessions with a different theme each week (Week 1: Our Ocean; Week 2: New England Habitat). Each day will have a hands-on science lesson, exploration of the HarborWalk (fishing and crabbing, planting in raised beds, etc.), and an art project related to the day’s theme. Through a partnership with the Boston Rowing Center, participants will also have the opportunity to learn rowing techniques before setting off to explore the Little Mystic and Boston Harbor by boat. 


How can you help? 

To cover the costs of this program, we must charge $400/week per child. However, it is very important to us that our participant group represents the diversity of the city. We are seeking funding to help subsidize the fee and make the camp more accessible to all families and we need your help! Any donations will go directly to a scholarship fund that will offset costs for low-income families. Our goal of raising $3200 will cover the cost for 8 Boston youth to attend our summer program and have the opportunity to explore the natural side of their city.


Who is "e" inc.?

“e” inc. brings in-depth science investigation programs to low-income communities throughout Greater Boston and has succeeded in capturing the interest of children who face academic, social, and economic challenges.  Our programs engage young people in hands-on science and, as their understanding grows, helps them build skills to make a difference.  It is this particular coupling of academics with community involvement that helps our children make, not just academic gains, but social growth, as well.

Past youth-led action projects have included: school-wide campaigns to save energy by turning off lights, making reusable bags, gardening and composting and writing letters to companies involved in deforestation. 

Our educators come with a wide range of experiences and talents. From mentoring at-risk youth to international work, "e" inc. educators' passion for the environment is only outmatched by their enthusiasm for working with youth. 

Find out more about our staff here: http://www.einc-action.org/our-educators.html


Why environment science? 

At “e” inc. we strongly believe that we are at a critical point in determining the future of our planet’s health. We are all aware of the environmental changes happening around the globe, from climate change to dwindling fish stocks; however, at “e” inc., the conversation doesn’t stop there. In addition to understanding the science behind these changes, we feel it is crucial to teach children that they have the power to make a difference. What may seem like a simple action has the power to inspire others and make change. Through hands-on experiences, “e” inc. kids learn to appreciate nature and are motivated to make a difference for the planet, all the while discovering their valuable place in the ecosystem.


But, don't just take it from us...


“I just wanted to tell you that today was the best. I faced two fears in one day – I held a crab AND got into a boat and rowed!” 
–Dorian, 11 year old from Dorchester, MA


“This is the best day ever! When I get home I’m going to tell my mom all about the sun’s energy!” 
– Kindergartner at Harvard-Kent Elementary School, Charlestown MA


"[The squid dissection and calamari lab] was the most delicious lesson
I’ve ever had!"
– 4th grade student from Jackson Mann Community Center, Boston, MA


"Thanks to "e" inc., our school is now salvaging buckets of untouched, packaged food, that was headed for the barrel and redistributing it to students in need of snacks." 
- Anthony Sharp, John F. Kennedy School Science Teacher, Somerville, MA


“"e" inc. is one of our most prized partnerships and I recommend their program to other schools with no reservations!” 
– Nicole Young, Josiah Quincy Elementary School, Community Partnership Coordinator, Boston, MA


For more information on “e” inc., check out our website:  www.einc-action.org
story_txt:
Growing up in a busy city
like Boston, Massachusetts, it is often difficult for urban youth to make the
connections between their daily lives and the natural world around them. Many
are unfamiliar with the marine species living just under the surface of the
Boston Harbor, or have never thought about how their usage of a plastic bag
could affect a sea turtle swimming in the Atlantic Ocean.
That’s
where “e” inc. comes in! “e” inc. – the environment science learning
and action center is a community-based non-profit whose mission is to
create scientifically-confident environmental citizens committed to
understanding and protecting the Earth. In 2013-2014 alone, “e” inc. provided civics and science sessions to well over 6,000 children and teens in school year residencies and summer intensives at over 20 Greater Boston schools, community centers and other educational institutions.Our ProjectThis year, “e” inc. is running its own Summer Science Discovery Program. The program will be based at the “e” inc. Discovery & Action Center in the Charlestown Navy Yard and is open to children ages 6-12. The program is comprised of two 1-week sessions with a different theme each week (Week 1: Our Ocean; Week 2: New England Habitat). Each day will have a hands-on science lesson, exploration of the HarborWalk (fishing and crabbing, planting in raised beds, etc.), and an art project related to the day’s theme. Through a partnership with the Boston Rowing Center, participants will also have the opportunity to learn rowing techniques before setting off to explore the Little Mystic and Boston Harbor by boat. How can you help? To cover the costs of this program, we must charge $400/week per child. However, it is very important to us that our participant group represents the diversity of the city. We are seeking funding to help subsidize the fee and make the camp more accessible to all families and we need your help! Any donations will go directly to a scholarship fund that will offset costs for low-income families. Our goal of raising $3200 will cover the cost for 8 Boston youth to attend our summer program and have the opportunity to explore the natural side of their city.Who is "e" inc.?

story:
Laughter is the bandaid for the heart! 

Help send Jpeace LoveCircus back to the earthquake devestated Nepal where he intends on helping the NAG school, Nawa Asha Griha, Home of New Hopes, a home and school for street children of Katmandu by teaching and performing Clown and Circus Arts for children in desperate need of joy. Continuing past training with NAG students, he will workshop and create a travelling show,  as well as go on mini circus tours with some of the older NAG students around the earthquake affected areas to help spread sustainable joy that will keep giving and help alleviate some of the tramatic stresses of the Nepali people. Planting circus seeds for tomorrow. 

In the winter of 2014 Jpeace and a team of talented artists joined together with the Musical Circus in teaching circus workshops and perfoming for the 200+ under privileged children of the Nag School.

 Now Jpeace intends on returning to his new friends and with some help, he and a small group of talented new Nepali circus stars will travel around performing for other children and communities effected by the major earthquake that has left their beautiful country in rubble. 

Not only bringing joy and circus skills to share, but also giving the gift of everlasting local community run social circus for future Nepali generations to come.

Circus and laughter have proven time and time again an amazing aid in speeding up childrens recovery time from tramatic events. Laughter and clowning help alleviate stresses as well as give a positive distraction in times of hardship promoting faster healing.  These moments also serve as great times to share a wide range of positive messages through clown and circus arts such as how to be safe, sticking together, positive thinking and other themes aimed at creating a healthy recovery of joy.

Friends, Family, and Supporters of Joy in the world: I can guarantee your donations will be graciously accepted and all of which will be put towards Nepal's loving heart. Consider your generous donations as a gift of joy and love as it will be sending a loving Clown into a disaster area to start a Circus of Nepali at-risk youth. A circus project which will need financial assistance to help cover travel costs, supplies, as well as water filter's and other emergency needs that the NAG school may need. I assure you this is a circus seed that will continue to spread joy along the long road to recovery for generations to come. 

I look forward to sharing the journey.

Thank you and may joy enhance us all.

story:
Who Are We?

Arts for All is a highly creative charity (charity no. 1096859) serving the disadvantaged communities of tower hamlets and Hackney. The organisation runs structured weekly art therapy sessions to engage people of all ages from divers cultures and background and those with special needs. The centre sits within one of the most deprived areas of the UK. Some 75% of the families served by the centre are unemployed and 50% have English as a second language. Through long-term support, Arts for all builds confidence, helps people achieve their goals and changes lives.

What Are We Gonna Do?

We're going to have a wild day out at Hever Castle in Kent (the ancestral home of Anne Boylen): coach trip, picnics, wonderful scenery and castle, archery, boating lake and ............. a full-blown reinactment of a Tudor jousting tournament attended by Henry VIII and Anne Boylen.

We know that many of the families and individuals who attend Arts For All are not in a position (for many reasons) to go out of London and do something so exciting and wonderful. We are committed to making this trip happen and would love your support. For those who chose to support this trip please be assured that, from our great experience, this day out will be life-changing for so many people and something that they will remember for ever!

ANY DONATIONS, NO MATTER HOW SMALL, WILL GO A LONG WAY! 

What We Need & What You Get

W need £1,860.00 to fund this trip. This breaks down as:
3 staff @ £15 per hour for 8 hours          £360.00
Coach                                                             £750.00
Hever Castle (house & garden)                £450.00
Costs of trip  (food, drink, icecream!)    £200.00
Extra costs                                                    £100.00
TOTAL                                                            £1,860.00
_____________________________________________________________________________
So...
WHAT DO YOU GET IN RETURN?!?! 
*There are 3 spaces to come and join us on this wonderful trip for EARLY BIRD DONATIONS!
All other donations will receive a bespoke mug, t-shirt or original piece of artwork created by one of our talented members at Arts For All.
More importantly, you have the joy of knowing that you have played your part in making this happen!
The Impact
As already mentioned you will get so much from the sheer knowledge that you have contributed, and had the opportunity to take part in this trip. Those who support us are always welcome to come to Shoreditch and visit us at any time.
In everything that we do at Arts For All our mission and vision is to see children, families and other vulnerable and disadvantaged members of the community grow in confidence through creativity and care, and move forward in their lives in a positive way. This in its turn effects the local community as people start to turn their lives around.
Arts For All has been running for 14 years and we have been on many exciting, varied and wonderful trips (in and out of London). We have always tried to give our members great opportunities and experiences.
We believe that THE FUN FACTOR is so IMPORTANT! Our trips are not all about education... the most important thing is that it makes them happy!
Risks & Challenges

We have a great deal of experience when it comes to taking children and families on trips. We have specific insurance for trips and wonderful experienced staff who are all CRB checked and have had child protection training. We have been to Hever Castle and have done a risk assessment and concluded that it is a place ideally suited for our needs.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Please do give a donation if you can and please this on social media and amongst friends and family!

    All the best and thank you!

    Arts For All 

    www.artsforall.co.uk

    www.facebook.com/artsforalluk

story:
Hunger for Information and Global Inclusion

After dual careers as a Pan Am flight attendant and a San Francisco-based financial planner and asset manager I chose to retire in Guatemala where I felt I could make a real difference with limited resources. I focus on education because I believe that it is one of the main cornerstones of development.

People in very rural communities will do almost anything to gain access to information, that same information that those of us with Internet access take for granted. We have had teachers walk six hours where there are no roads to receive hardware and the training of how to use the Internet-based educational content in the unconnected classroom. The technology training and the classroom training that we provide makes it possible for the students to be more engaged and learn more easily.

Thanks to a small, inexpensive computer called a "Raspberry Pi" and free, open source educational content called RACHEL (Rural Area Community Hotspots for Education and Learning) compiled by World Possible we can now satisfy that yearning for information and contact with the global community. 


The hardware costs less than $200 and the content, including Wikipedia, Khan Academy, Hesperian Health Guides, the Guatemalan National Curriculum, books from the Gutenberg project and more, is FREE. Our challenge is in reaching the rural communities who are asking us to bring them RACHEL (Rural Area Community Hotspots for Education and Learning). Guatemala is the size of Tennessee but with a far more challenging topography that includes thirty-three volcanos and many unpaved, marginally navigable roads.


In the two years since the launch of the Spanish language version of RACHEL we have done installations in over sixty communities and have provided training to 743 teachers.  Sixty-five schools serving over fourteen thousand students and using RACHEL today. In addition, we have installed RACHEL in fifteen public libraries. Our waiting list grows daily.

We Need a Truck to Reach Rural Communities

If we reach our goal all of the funds will go towards buying a new or late model sturdy, reliable, four-wheel drive truck. We currently travel in an SUV vehicle that is just not up to some of the mountainous, unpaved, high altitude roads. Our team needs to be both safe and secure in order to continue providing information in the most rural parts of the country where there is no hope of Internet in the near future.

If we don't reach our goal we will approach previous donors and ask them to help us buy a truck. The truck will carry the logo of "Mundo Posible" adding to our exposure throughout the country. 

The Impact

In December we gained the attention of and met with Guatemala's Vice-President, Dr. Jafeth Cabrera and his Minister of Education, Oscar Lopez. Very quickly the two figured out that a Raspberry Pi was cheaper than textbooks. Most rural schools have neither as government spending on education in Guatemala is negligible. It is the most rural communities that are least likely to have any resources for their schools. Internet access for the schools is only a dream. However many residents have smart phones and some schools have donated computers and tablets which allow them to access the RACHEL content. It is these communities that we would like to reach with your help. 

Risks & Challenges

Without an appropriate vehicle our team often has to travel on the local public transportation, known affectionately as the "chicken bus." In the mountainous rural regions service is often limited and even dangerous for those carrying valuable and bulky hardware.

With a truck we will be able to reach communities where there is no bus service and where the roads are barely passable and sometimes non-existent.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone is in a position to donate. If you are unable to do so please share this campaign with your friends especially those with a passion for education and improving things for the people of Guatemala.

story:
A STEAM Camp in Guinea

Guinea is one of the least developed countries in the world, rated 182nd in the Human Development Index and recently ravaged by an Ebola epidemic. From these facts alone, it is no surprise that the educational system in Guinea is broken, and Guinean students are left behind in the dust. Guinea desperately needs health care providers, infrastructure engineers, well-trained teachers, and many more well educated professionals. However, relatively few development organizations are on the ground in Guinea, compared to nearby Sierra Leone, Liberia, and Senegal. Cultural barriers are high, especially for English-speaking and Christian charities in this Francophone, primarily Muslim country. And yet, innovative, curious, determined young Guineans are just begging for the chance to learn more and expand their horizons. Luckily, we’ve assembled a team that is uniquely capable of helping youth in Guinea expand their horizons, and we’re going to start this summer through a STEAM camp.

The Hope of Guinea STEAM ( Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts and Science) Camp 2016 that will take place from July 11th to July 29th and is a joint initiative between Hope of Guinea, MindLeaps, and Returned Peace Corps Volunteers from Guinea. The STEAM Camp is based on a successful project designed and implemented by Peace Corps Volunteers in the summer of 2014. 

          

Well into implementation, the concept of the camp is to provide resources and innovative ways of learning to kids in Guinea whether in  school or on the street. Hope of Guinea aims to provide hope to all children with its first STEAM Camp. For three weeks, from Monday through Thursday, selected kids of junior high age will perform experiments, participate in engaging field trips, and develop techniques in traditional and non traditional dance forms. 

Planned experimental activities include: chicken dissection, microscope skill lessons, a bridge building competition, DNA extraction, a game modeling disease spread, and the creation of electromagnets. Several field trips are planned, such as a visit to a hydroelectric dam and a sustainable farm. 

One of our partners, MindLeaps, will bring lessons on traditional Guinean dance, hip-hop, and classical ballet. Instructors will praise effort and use growth mindset tools like summarizing to help students access long-term memory.  A "growth mindset" is a way of learning that is supported by research in neuroplasticity and psychology. It encourages critical thinking and failure, two aspects of learning that are never emphasized in the memorization-bound Guinean education system. We believe that by opening our students eyes to a "growth mindset" and engaging them fully through art and dance in addition to science, engineering, math and critical thinking skills, we can make a lasting impact on the leaders of today and tomorrow.

 

We Need Your Support... How You Can Help & Why

We need to raise $30,296 to successfully run, evaluate and begin expanding this program so that it has a long term impact that not only works to give the students the tools to empower themselves but also tools for teachers in country to help sustain and incorporate growth mindset within Guinea's educational system. Small changes can have a big impact and your support makes the difference in how big that impact is.

The funds raised will cover the following expenses:

  • Materials required to teach the curriculum and for participants to design and build projects and experiments;
  • Materials  and curriculum for local instructors to take back to their schools after the camp to create after-school science clubs;
  • Create 5 year around after-school STEAM clubs at 5 different schools;
  • Food and snacks for the participants;
  • Round trip flights to/from Guinea for our instructors;
  • Modest stipends for our volunteer staff;
  • Lodging and transportation for international instructors;
  • Advertising and branding;
  • Internet usage during the camp;
  • Pre- and post-camp assessment and evaluations for all camp participants.

The Impact

One very successful event that members of our team led was a National Science Camp. We’re using the framework from that, combined with current learning methods and artistic outlets to make a significant change in the lives of the 50 students and 5 teachers at our camps. We know from previous camps that students introduced to new, exciting experiences will go home with confidence and a new found curiosity in exploring STEAM and its correlation to the challenges that their communities face. Additionally, we will be training 5 Guinean teachers from across the country on how to run camps like this one in their own schools. Not only will they participate in our camp, but they’ll go home with a written guide and materials that they would never have been able to procure otherwise, like microscopes, calculators, and test tubes. Once our camp is finished at the end of July, we will encourage the teachers to organize their own camps, ideally right before school starts in October and create after-school science clubs. If each of our five teachers holds a camp with 30 students per semester, our project will have been responsible for bringing scientific discovery to 300 students in one year. 
We are currently in the process of creating a tool to assess the camp and the impact that our 5 teachers will have. We are committed to giving hope to Guinea's future STEAM leaders and hope you join us in our initiative. 


What You Can Get

All donors, if they choose so, will receive perks based on their gift. Donations of $500 and above are offered unique perks that are made in Guinea.

$500 Level Perk - Tailored Bazin: the Bazin is a traditional ceremonial dress for both men and women in Guinea. Each Bazin will be specially made in Guinea (similar, though not exact, to the pictures below).

           

                     


$1000 Level Perk - The Nimba Sculpture: the Nimba is the most well known sculpture from Guinea. We will have a Nimba made for you with your name inscribed on its base. 

                                       


$5000 Level Perk- Your name will be listed on our website and marketing materials as an official sponsor of the program. You'll also receive all of our perks including the Tailored Bazin and the Nimba Sculpture pictured above.

Other Ways You Can Help


Hope of Guinea is a 501c(3) tax-exempt charitable organization under IRS section 170(b)(2)(iii), so we will be able to provide you with a federal tax identification number. Gifts to Hope of Guinea are tax-deductible to the fullest extent of the law.
story_txt:
A STEAM Camp in Guinea

Guinea is
one of the least developed countries in the world, rated 182nd in the Human
Development Index and recently ravaged by an Ebola epidemic. From these facts alone, it is
no surprise that the educational system in Guinea is broken, and Guinean students
are left behind in the dust. Guinea desperately needs health care
providers, infrastructure engineers, well-trained teachers, and many more well
educated professionals. However, relatively few development organizations are
on the ground in Guinea, compared to nearby Sierra Leone, Liberia, and Senegal.
Cultural barriers are high, especially for English-speaking and Christian
charities in this Francophone, primarily Muslim country. And yet, innovative,
curious, determined young Guineans are just begging for the chance to learn
more and expand their horizons. Luckily, we’ve assembled a team that is
uniquely capable of helping youth in Guinea expand their horizons, and we’re
going to start this summer through a STEAM camp.
The Hope
of Guinea STEAM ( Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts and Science) Camp 2016
that will take place from July 11th to July 29th and is a joint initiative
between Hope of Guinea, MindLeaps, and Returned Peace Corps Volunteers from
Guinea. The STEAM Camp is based on a successful project designed and
implemented by Peace Corps Volunteers in the summer of 2014. 




          



Well into implementation, the concept of the camp is to provide resources and innovative ways of learning to kids in Guinea whether in  school or on the street. Hope of Guinea aims to provide hope to all children with its first STEAM Camp. For three weeks, from Monday through Thursday, selected kids of junior high age will perform experiments, participate in engaging field trips, and develop techniques in traditional and non traditional dance forms. 
Planned experimental activities include: chicken dissection, microscope skill lessons, a bridge building competition, DNA extraction, a game modeling disease spread, and the creation of electromagnets. Several field trips are planned, such as a visit to a hydroelectric dam and a sustainable farm. 
One of our partners, MindLeaps, will bring lessons on traditional Guinean dance, hip-hop, and classical ballet. Instructors will praise effort and use growth mindset tools like summarizing to help students access long-term memory.  A "growth mindset" is a way of learning that is supported by research in neuroplasticity and psychology. It encourages critical thinking and failure, two aspects of learning that are never emphasized in the memorization-bound Guinean education system. We believe that by opening our students eyes to a "growth mindset" and engaging them fully through art and dance in addition to science, engineering, math and critical thinking skills, we can make a lasting impact on the leaders of today and tomorrow.

 


We Need Your Support... How You Can Help & Why 


We need to raise $30,296 to successfully run, evaluate and begin expanding this program so that it has a long term impact that not only works to give the students the tools to empower themselves but also tools for teachers in country to help sustain and incorporate growth mindset within Guinea's educational system. Small changes can have a big impact and your support makes the difference in how big that impact is.
The funds raised will cover the following expenses:

Materials required to teach the
     curriculum and for participants to design and build projects and
     experiments;
Materials  and curriculum for local instructors to
     take back to their schools after the camp to create after-school science
     clubs;
Create 5 year around after-school
     STEAM clubs at 5 different schools;
Food and snacks for the
     participants;
Round trip flights to/from Guinea
     for our instructors;
Modest stipends for our volunteer
     staff;
Lodging and transportation for
     international instructors;
Advertising and branding;
Internet usage during the camp;
Pre- and post-camp assessment and evaluations for all camp participants.



The Impact

One very successful event that members of our
team led was a National Science Camp. We’re using the framework from that,
combined with current learning methods and artistic outlets to make a
significant change in the lives of the 50 students and 5 teachers at our camps.
We know from previous camps that students introduced to new, exciting
experiences will go home with confidence and a new found curiosity in exploring STEAM and its correlation to the challenges that their communities face. Additionally, we will be training 5 Guinean teachers from across the country on
how to run camps like this one in their own schools. Not only will they
participate in our camp, but they’ll go home with a written guide and materials
that they would never have been able to procure otherwise, like microscopes,
calculators, and test tubes. Once our camp is finished at the end of July, we
will encourage the teachers to organize their own camps, ideally right before
school starts in October and create after-school science clubs. If each of our
five teachers holds a camp with 30 students per semester, our project will have
been responsible for bringing scientific discovery to 300 students in one year. 
We are currently in the process of creating a tool to assess the camp and the impact that our 5 teachers will have. We are committed to giving hope to Guinea's future STEAM leaders and hope you join us in our initiative. 






What You Can Get


All donors, if they choose so, will
receive perks based on their gift. Donations of $500
and above are offered unique perks that are made in Guinea.

$500
Level Perk
- Tailored Bazin: the Bazin is a traditional ceremonial dress for both men and
women in Guinea. Each Bazin will be specially made in Guinea (similar, though not exact, to the pictures below).


           
                     

$1000
Level Perk
- The Nimba Sculpture: the Nimba is the most well known sculpture from Guinea. We will have a Nimba made for you with your name inscribed on its base. 

                                       


$5000 Level Perk- Your name will
be listed on our website and marketing materials as an official sponsor of the
program. You'll also receive all of our perks including the Tailored Bazin and
the Nimba Sculpture pictured above.


Other Ways You Can Help



Hope of Guinea is a 501c(3) tax-exempt charitable organization under IRS section 170(b)(2)(iii), so we will be able to provide you with a federal tax identification number. Gifts to Hope of Guinea are tax-deductible to the fullest extent of the law.

story:
Short Summary

Hi, I'm Cam Hawkins, I run a popular financial trading podcast called 52 Traders where I interview successful financial traders from around the world to see what makes them tick. 

Today I'd like to let you into my world and share with you the skills I've acquired through my unique approach to trading via a "tell all" online course that is guaranteed to reduce risk, save you time trading and put you in a better position when it comes to earning a "passive income" as a trader. 

On top of all this.. it's FUN!

But first, here's my story...

For the past 7 years my trading career has mainly revolved around automating my trading. I’m not the type of person who enjoys sitting watching charts and waiting for trade setups to occur and when I stumbled across automated trading I thought I’d found the answer!

It allowed me to use software (aka trading robots) that would do all the work for me and enter and exit trades when certain criteria were met (these criteria are based on trading strategies - strategies can be conjured up using simple math and a bunch of tools readily available to you). 

However, after I spent thousands of dollars buying automated trading robots, with no success, I turned to developers to build my trading strategies into robots... only to find they had no vested interest in making these robots profitable. This cost me a small fortune!

Then I ended up trying a different approach... and I want to create a course to teach you everything I know about building, testing, optimizing and trading these robots.

I want to give you the opportunity to learn all about these trading robots:

  • how to build them
  • how to test they work and match your trading strategy 
  • how to optimize them to find the "most" profitable settings
  • how to trade them live or on a demo account with a broker

... all before you let them loose on the markets to trade for you on autopilot earning you that "passive income" - while you sleep, spend time with friends/family or go shopping to spend all the money you're making!

So, here’s everything you need to know about the trading robots you will end up building:

  • The trading platform I use is called Metatrader 4 or MT4. There are 1000’s of brokers all around the world who let you download this trading platform for FREE. You simply open a demo or live account with them - you don't even need to fund the account. 
  • MT4 runs on a Windows PC (sorry about that Mac users) and connects to your broker through the internet.
  • The software plugin that automates trades for you (aka the Trading Robot) is called an Expert Advisor or EA and this plugs into Metatrader 4.
  • And the software I use to build EA’s is called FxDreema.

FxDreema can be used for free with some limitations. This gives you the time to learn it or simply "try it out". 

When you need to use the full version of FxDreema and unlock the limitations, you will need to pay a small fee which FxDreema allows you to pay for in blocks. 

The great thing about their model is that you’re not stuck in a contract or anything like that. A three month block seems to be the most affordable at $11 per month while a one month block costs $19. Plus, you can get it for as low as $7.90 per month if you lock yourself in for a year like I do. It basically works out at the same cost as a trip to McDonald's once a month for one person!

And remember, I'm including a FREE 3 month FxDreema subscription for anyone who takes up the Full Course perk.

Click here to see the full FxDreema subscription model

What I Need & What You Get

The course I plan to create will teach you how to use FxDreema to build EA’s based on trading strategies (I provide some high quality trading strategies in the course that you can practice on if you don't have any of your own). I'll then teach you how you ensure your strategy is profitable by back testing it on the historical market data. You can test it on things like Fx, Commodities, Metals and Indicies in before you trade it using real money.

Full Course:

By joining here on Indiegogo you'll become a "Founding Member" and get the contents of the Full Course which is as follows:

  • A complete FxDreema EA Builder course - Value: $1997
  • Dedicated MT4 testing platform - Value: $800
  • 10 FxDreema Templates - Value: $300
  • 10 Proven Trading Strategies - Value: $1,000
  • 3 Month FREE FxDreema Subscription - Value: $57
  • Community Access - Value: $1000
  • BONUS Candy Shop EA: FxDreema Template & Optimized MT4 Settings

Below is a visual demonstration of the time you will save using the course versus trying to do it yourself (DIY). You'll see that by your third or fourth strategy you'll be creating it in hours versus weeks or even months. That's the benefit of having a course walk you through everything!

The funding...

Today I need your help funding this project because:

  • I estimate it will take me in excess of 200 hours to create the course. That's 4 weeks, working 8 hour days. So I'm basically looking for your help to subsidize the hours I'll put into creating the course at a subsidized rate of $20/hr, i.e. $20 X 200 = $4,000.
  • There are also additional costs associated with the ongoing running of the website where you will login to learn the course content
  • I also want to know that people are interested in this type of course
  • I also want your feedback on how the course is structured so that it can meet the needs of all my students from the least to the most technical and those new to trading versus the experienced trader
  • I know that courses are followed and people learn and apply the skills when people have a "vested interest" and helping fund the course will be your vested interest and help with your learning and enjoyment

If I meet the funding goal I will aim to complete the course within 45 days. 

I have made a promise that the course (should it go ahead) will be priced at no less than $497 USD when it is complete. So as a Founding member, here on Indiegogo, you will have access to it at a much lower investment. 

To learn more about what's on offer and a strategy you can use when applying this course please take the time to watch this webinar I recorded recently for my subscribers "3 Secrets to Acquiring Profitable MT4 EA's". In the webinar you will see some content that is not relevant to the Indiegogo offer, please ignore this.


The Impact

I’ve touched on just a few of the benefits to using this approach to trade the markets and I know that the upside potential is huge. 

As part of my podcast I have interviewed 3 different traders who make a significant living trading a handful of automated strategies consecutively, while they enjoy a life most of us only dream of through the Passive Income they create!

You can listen to 2 of the interviews on my podcast website here:

  • Kevin Davey interview
  • Tim Rea interview
Today I want to share my knowledge to make that kind of life available for you too!
On top of this, there are many ways (outside of trading the markets using these robots) that can generate you a passive income and I'll include details of these within the course. 
In some cases you can make more money with these strategies than through trading alone.

Risks & Challenges

The main risk is me. If something were to happen to me that would prevent me from finishing the course within 45 days I would first look to see if an acceptable date could be accommodated by asking you first and those that do not want to wait that long will be refunded. I'll also drip feed finished content into the course when it is ready so that you do not have to wait until all the content is finished - hence reducing the risk further.

I have all the software, tools and websites in place to publish the course so there are no risks with regard to members having access to the content. It's just the content generation that is still required.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you like the idea of this course and want to help and don't have the funds it would be great (and much appreciated) if you could paste a link to this page on any trading forums, blogs or trading communities you belong to.

Many Thanks!

Cam

story:
I.  Short Summary:

Building Future Global Leaders for Peace through Education & Arts:

The Genesis Academy Summer Institute 2016

Since 1999, Genesis at the Crossroads has been building peace programs around the world through arts and education.  In 2015, Genesis launched the Genesis Academy Summer Institute, which brought together global youth for a transformational educational experience.  Within the next three years, the Summer Institute will evolve into the summer quarter of the Genesis Academy for Global Leadership – a four-year boarding high school for global youth offering an experiential curriculum that fosters critical thinking, cross-cultural collaboration and understanding through the arts fully integrated into the humanities and sciences. 

Our 2015 Summer Institute brought together young adults ages 15-19 from conflict and post-conflict zones to learn experientially in four curricular areas:  heroes and human rights, music and peacebuilding, environmental sustainability and peace journalism.  The 2016 Summer Institute will bring in a new cohort of students to learn in cross-cultural teams – a process that cultivates respect and understanding across boundaries, languages and points of view.  The students will creatively engage with the arts in an inter-disciplinary curriculum that fosters critical thinking, innovation, cooperation and humanism. 

https://soundcloud.com/wbez-worldview/global-activism-genesis-at-the-crossroads

Genesis’ Founder and Executive, Dr. Wendy Sternberg, has built Genesis at the Crossroads over the past 16 years into a thriving peacebuilding organization, forging global partnerships with 45+ institutions on five continents.  She masterminds the creative development/management of inquiry-based salon programs at the nexus of human rights, human development and the arts and founded Saffron Caravan, uniting musicians from Iran, Afghanistan, Cuba, Morocco, Israel, India, Bosnia, Brazil, Japan and the US for cross-cultural collaborative performance and educational programs.  (Please see the link below.)

Under her leadership, Genesis boasts over 100 award-winning programs, internationally-acclaimed by the UN, The Kennedy Center, Rotary International, The King of Morocco, the British Council, the US Institute of Peace and the US State Department.  Rotary International selected her as one of 22 world leaders for their 2009 Peace Fellowship.  In 2014, marking the 100th anniversary of World War I, she was selected along with 59 other global activists, to be a Salzburg Global Seminar Fellow and participate in an international consortium on the power of arts and culture to transform our world.  A participant in the Clinton Global Initiative, she configured the Genesis Academy for Global Leadership as a scalable global model for peace education (her CGI commitment.) Her medical career informs the healing aspects at the heart of Genesis.

II.  What We Need + What You Get:

We need to raise $150,000 USD to bring 20 global students to the 2016 Summer Institute.  These funds will cover not only  international travel + room and board (at a university center), but also all ground transportation, supplies/educational materials, faculty honoraria, field studies, admission for all museums and other visited institutions, and the final closing ceremony showcasing their work. 

(All surplus funds go towards future Genesis Academy Summer Institutes and building The Genesis Academy for Global Leadership, a $34 million boarding high-school school with endowed scholarships for its future students.)

The Perks:

Depending upon your level of support, our peacebuilding-perk gifts range the gamut from your very own Genesis Saffron Caravan CD or a unique set of our peace quilt cards designed by children with their vision for world peace, a Genesis guitar pick or a personalized engraved brick along the Genesis Academy’s Path to Peace.  You can have your name proudly displayed on our website for funding a student's travel or full scholarship.  Greater investment on your part, could create your personal sponsorship of a Saffron Caravan concert to help us raise even more...

III. Impact

In this conflict-saturated world, we believe innovative education will provide the most powerful way to address and solve intractable problems and thereby, transform humanity. 

What if you had a hand in helping us find next-generation global youth leaders and invest in them by supporting this unique educational program? 

Giving to the 2016 Genesis Academy Summer Institute empowers you to bring real opportunity not only to conflict-torn areas of the world, but also to the future prospects for peace by nurturing bright, young leaders through the arts and a rich experiential curriculum.  Moreover, it helps lay the foundation (within the next three years), for building the Genesis Academy for Global Leadership:  a four-year boarding high school in Chicago that will immerse future leaders in four years of the same arts-rich curriculum, designed by experts. 

When students work and learn in cross-cultural teams, they learn to respect one another and appreciate diverse perspectives different from their own.  An inter-disciplinary curriculum embedded with art cultivates both their critical thinking and humanism.  Our Academy, which incorporates an incubator- lab for academic studies on creativity and leadership, engages our four university partners: University of Pennsylvania, Stanford University School of Medicine Center for Compassion and Altruism, Indiana University Lilly Family School of Philanthropy and DePaul University. (Others are in progress...)

Genesis at the Crossroads has been healing conflict through education and the arts for 16 years.  The 2015 Summer Institute already enriched the lives of young people from conflict and post- conflict zones around the world.  Our students came from Pakistan, Cambodia, Northern Ireland, Bosnia, and the US.  Together, they explored many complex issues locally and globally, accomplished professionally crafted blogs, recorded podcasts of renowned heroes working in human rights and environmental sustainability, created frameworks for children’s stories addressing pressing global issues and wrote the lyrics and score for an original song and professionally recorded it in a music studio.  They created photography exhibits, journaled about their personal journey, and became a community of internationally-networked youth leaders - “Ambassadors for Peacebuilding.”

IV.  Risks and Challenges:

We have a 16-year proven track record of doing educational and artistic programs in a variety of settings in and outside the classroom and of producing programs all over the world, some in times of great challenge– from Morocco, to Jerusalem and the Bedouin community during the Arab Spring, to Bosnia in the 20th anniversary year of the genocide in the former Yugoslavia - to those at home in Chicago and across the US. We have faced visa issues for artists and students, prevailed despite conflict crises worldwide, and continue to employ a smart, creative and tenacious team of artists, educators and managers to deliver our programs. 

The Summer Institute gives us not only valuable experience, partnerships and expertise, but also helps us build a coalition and network of supporters to realize the vision of the Genesis Academy for Global Leadership.  In the longer term, we face the challenges of building this new school in Chicago – a four-year boarding high school that will include the Summer Institute as its summer quarter.  We need to purchase land, build the facilities, furnish technology and libraries, develop curricula, pay teachers and artists, and house our students.  This vision requires expertise and a budget of $34 million USD.  We look forward to also endowing scholarships to make this financially accessible for qualified, talented students from all over the world.

While some have suggested we use a closed-down school and build the boarding school at a later date, we prefer to build our educational movement, model and our institutional legacy with our vision for a boarding community that engages young people in transformative education in social justice, human rights and the arts while they live and learn together.  If this takes a few years beyond 2018, we will continue the Genesis Academy Summer Institute as is, along with all of our other Saffron Caravan and Salon programs, in the meantime – we think it will be worth the wait!


Other Ways to Provide Service:

  • Media skills

  • Subject matter expertise in curriculum development

  • Finance/Asset management skills

  • Project managerial or executive assistance support

  • Fundraising/Development support

  • Help identify promising youth leaders

  • Share Genesis with your community and spread the word


Please share our story...share our website - www.gatc.org

Peace education and true peacebuilding happen in incremental steps. 

YOUR support speeds up the process. 

We ALL benefit.

Thank you in advance for your generosity!


To learn more about Genesis at the Crossroads and Saffron Caravan:

https://m.soundcloud.com/wbez-worldview/genesis-at-the-crossroads-presents-saffron-caravan

http://www.usip.org/events/using-the-arts-promote-human-rights-in-peacebuilding
